text: implanted in the human mind that it ought to be counted among eternal truths

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and axioms.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (16:31) As a necessary consequence of the principle just enunciated, no one
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: can honestly promise to forego the right which he has over all things
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [Endnote 26], and in general no one will abide by his promises, unless under
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the fear of a greater evil, or the hope of a greater good. (32) An example
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will make the matter clearer. (33) Suppose that a robber forces me to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: promise that I will give him my goods at his will and pleasure. (34) It is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: plain (inasmuch as my natural right is, as I have shown, co-extensive with
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: my power) that if I can free myself from this robber by stratagem, by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: assenting to his demands, I have the natural right to do so, and to pretend
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to accept his conditions. (35) Or again, suppose I have genuinely promised
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: someone that for the space of twenty days I will not taste food or any
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nourishment; and suppose I afterwards find that was foolish, and cannot be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: kept without very great injury to myself; as I am bound by natural law and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: right to choose the least of two evils, I have complete right to break my
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: compact, and act as if my promise had never been uttered. (36) I say that I
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: should have perfect natural right to do so, whether I was actuated by true
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and evident reason, or whether I was actuated by mere opinion in thinking I
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: had promised rashly; whether my reasons were true or false, I should be in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fear of a greater evil, which, by the ordinance of nature, I should strive
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to avoid by every means in my power.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (16:37) We may, therefore, conclude that a compact is only made valid by its
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: utility, without which it becomes null and void. (38) It is, therefore,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: foolish to ask a man to keep his faith with us for ever, unless we also
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endeavour that the violation of the compact we enter into shall involve for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the violator more harm than good. (39) This consideration should have very
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: great weight in forming a state. (40) However, if all men could be easily
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: led by reason alone, and could recognize what is best and most useful for a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: state, there would be no one who would not forswear deceit, for everyone
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: would keep most religiously to their compact in their desire for the chief
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: good, namely, the shield and buckler of the commonwealth. (41) However, it
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is far from being the case that all men can always be easily led by reason
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: alone; everyone is drawn away by his pleasure, while avarice, ambition,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: envy, hatred, and the like so engross the mind that, reason has no place
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therein. (42) Hence, though men make - promises with all the appearances of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: good faith, and agree that they will keep to their engagement, no one can
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: absolutely rely on another man's promise unless there is something behind
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it. (43) Everyone has by nature a right to act deceitfully, and to break his
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: compacts, unless he be restrained by the hope of some greater good, or the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fear of some greater evil.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (16:44) However, as we have shown that the natural right of the individual
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is only limited by his power, it is clear that by transferring, either
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: willingly or under compulsion, this power into the hands of another, he in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so doing necessarily cedes also a part of his right; and further, that the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Sovereign right over all men belongs to him who has sovereign power,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wherewith he can compel men by force, or restrain them by threats of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: universally feared punishment of death; such sovereign right he will
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: retain only so long as he can maintain his power of enforcing his will;
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: otherwise he will totter on his throne, and no one who is stronger than he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will be bound unwillingly to obey him.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (16:45) In this manner a society can be formed without any violation of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: natural right, and the covenant can always be strictly kept - that is, if
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: each individual hands over the whole of his power to the body politic, the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: latter will then possess sovereign natural right over all things; that is,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it will have sole and unquestioned dominion, and everyone will be bound to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: obey, under pain of the severest punishment. (46) A body politic of this
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: kind is called a Democracy, which may be defined as a society which wields
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: all its power as a whole. (47) The sovereign power is not restrained by any
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: laws, but everyone is bound to obey it in all things; such is the state of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things implied when men either tacitly or expressly handed over to it all
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their power of self-defence, or in other words, all their right. (48) For if
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they had wished to retain any right for themselves, they ought to have taken
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: precautions for its defence and preservation; as they have not done so,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and indeed could not have done so without dividing and consequently ruining
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the state, they placed themselves absolutely at the mercy of the sovereign
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: power; and, therefore, having acted (as we have shown) as reason and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessity demanded, they are obliged to fulfil the commands of the sovereign
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: power, however absurd these may be, else they will be public enemies, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will act against reason, which urges the preservation of the state as a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: primary duty. (49) For reason bids us choose the least of two evils.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (16:50) Furthermore, this danger of submitting absolutely to the dominion
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and will of another, is one which may be incurred with a light heart: for we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have shown that sovereigns only possess this right of imposing their will,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so long as they have the full power to enforce it: if such power be lost
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their right to command is lost also, or lapses to those who have assumed it
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and can keep it. (51) Thus it is very rare for sovereigns to impose
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thoroughly irrational commands, for they are bound to consult their own
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: interests, and retain their power by consulting the public good and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: acting according to the dictates of reason, as Seneca says, "violenta
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imperia nemo continuit diu." (52) No one can long retain a tyrant's sway.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (16:53) In a democracy, irrational commands are still less to be feared: for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it is almost impossible that the majority of a people, especially if it be a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: large one, should agree in an irrational design: and, moreover, the basis
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and aim of a democracy is to avoid the desires as irrational, and to bring
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: men as far as possible under the control of reason, so that they may live in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: peace and harmony: if this basis be removed the whole fabric falls to ruin.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (16:54) Such being the ends in view for the sovereign power, the duty of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: subjects is, as I have said, to obey its commands, and to recognize no right
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: save that which it sanctions.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [16:4] (55) It will, perhaps, be thought that we are turning subjects into
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: slaves: for slaves obey commands and free men live as they like; but this
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: idea is based on a misconception, for the true slave is he who is led away
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by his pleasures and can neither see what is good for him nor act
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: accordingly: he alone is free who lives with free consent under the entire
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: guidance of reason.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (16:56) Action in obedience to orders does take away freedom in a certain
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sense, but it does not, therefore, make a man a slave, all depends on the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: object of the action. (57) If the object of the action be the good of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: state, and not the good of the agent, the latter is a slave and does
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: himself no good: but in a state or kingdom where the weal of the whole
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: people, and not that of the ruler, is the supreme law, obedience to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sovereign power does not make a man a slave, of no use to himself, but a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: subject. (58) Therefore, that state is the freest whose laws are founded on
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sound reason, so that every member of it may, if he will, be free [Endnote
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: 27]; that is, live with full consent under the entire guidance of reason.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (16:59) Children, though they are bound to obey all the commands of their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: parents, are yet not slaves: for the commands of parents look generally to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the children's benefit.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (60) We must, therefore, acknowledge a great difference between a slave, a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: son, and a subject; their positions may be thus defined. (61) A slave is one
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: who is bound to obey his master's orders, though they are given solely in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the master's interest: a son is one who obeys his father's orders, given
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in his own interest; a subject obeys the orders of the sovereign power,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: given for the common interest, wherein he is included.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (16:62) I think I have now shown sufficiently clearly the basis of a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: democracy: I have especially desired to do so, for I believe it to be of all
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: forms of government the most natural, and the most consonant with individual
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: liberty. (63) In it no one transfers his natural right so absolutely that he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: has no further voice in affairs, he only hands it over to the majority of a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: society, whereof he is a unit. Thus all men remain as they were in the state
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of nature, equals.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (16:64) This is the only form of government which I have treated of at
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: length, for it is the one most akin to my purpose of showing the benefits of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: freedom in a state.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (65) I may pass over the fundamental principles of other forms of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: government, for we may gather from what has been said whence their right
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: arises without going into its origin. (66) The possessor of sovereign power,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whether he be one, or many, or the whole body politic, has the sovereign
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: right of imposing any commands he pleases: and he who has either
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: voluntarily, or under compulsion, transferred the right to defend him to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: another, has, in so doing, renounced his natural right and is therefore
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: bound to obey, in all things, the commands of the sovereign power; and will
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be bound so to do so long as the king, or nobles, or the people preserve the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sovereign power which formed the basis of the original transfer. (67) I need
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: add no more.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [16:5] (68) The bases and rights of dominion being thus displayed, we shall
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: readily be able to define private civil right, wrong, justice, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: injustice, with their relations to the state; and also to determine what
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: constitutes an ally, or an enemy, or the crime of treason.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (16:69) By private civil right we can only mean the liberty every man
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: possesses to preserve his existence, a liberty limited by the edicts of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sovereign power, and preserved only by its authority: for when a man has
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: transferred to another his right of living as he likes, which was only
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: limited by his power, that is, has transferred his liberty and power of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: self-defence, he is bound to live as that other dictates, and to trust to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: him entirely for his defence. (70) Wrong takes place when a citizen, or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: subject, is forced by another to undergo some loss or pain in contradiction
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to the authority of the law, or the edict of the sovereign power.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (16:71) Wrong is conceivable only in an organized community: nor can it ever
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: accrue to subjects from any act of the sovereign, who has the right to do
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: what he likes. (72) It can only arise, therefore, between private persons,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: who are bound by law and right not to injure one another. (73) Justice
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consists in the habitual rendering to every man his lawful due: injustice
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consists in depriving a man, under the pretence of legality, of what the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: laws, rightly interpreted, would allow him. (74) These last are also called
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: equity and iniquity, because those who administer the laws are bound to show
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: no respect of persons, but to account all men equal, and to defend every
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man's right equally, neither envying the rich nor despising the poor.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [16:6](75) The men of two states become allies, when for the sake of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: avoiding war, or for some other advantage, they covenant to do each other no
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hurt, but on the contrary, to assist each other if necessity arises, each
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: retaining his independence. (76) Such a covenant is valid so long as its
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: basis of danger or advantage is in force: no one enters into an engagement,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or is bound to stand by his compacts unless there be a hope of some accruing
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: good, or the fear of some evil: if this basis be removed the compact thereby
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: becomes void: this has been abundantly shown by experience. (77) For
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: although different states make treaties not to harm one another, they always
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: take every possible precaution against such treaties being broken by the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: stronger party, and do not rely on the compact, unless there is a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sufficiently obvious object and advantage to both parties in observing it.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (78) Otherwise they would fear a breach of faith, nor would there be any
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wrong done thereby: for who in his proper senses, and aware of the right of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the sovereign power, would trust in the promises of one who has the will and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the power to do what he likes, and who aims solely at the safety and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: advantage of his dominion? (79) Moreover, if we consult loyalty and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: religion, we shall see that no one in possession of power ought to abide by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his promises to the injury of his dominion; for he cannot keep such promises
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: without breaking the engagement he made with his subjects, by which both he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and they are most solemnly bound. (80) An enemy is one who lives apart from
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the state, and does not recognize its authority either as a subject or as an
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ally. It is not hatred which makes a man an enemy, but the rights of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: state. (81) The rights of the state are the same in regard to him who
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: does not recognize by any compact the state authority, as they are against
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: him who has done the state an injury: it has the right to force him as best
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it can, either to submit, or to contract an alliance.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [16:7] (82) Lastly, treason can only be committed by subjects, who by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: compact, either tacit or expressed, have transferred all their rights to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: state: a subject is said to have committed this crime when he has attempted,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for whatever reason, to seize the sovereign power, or to place it in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: different hands. (83) I say, has attempted, for if punishment were not to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: overtake him till he had succeeded, it would often come too late, the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sovereign rights would have been acquired or transferred already.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (16:84) I also say, has attempted, for whatever reason, to seize the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sovereign power, and I recognize no difference whether such an attempt
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: should be followed by public loss or public gain. (85) Whatever be his
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason for acting, the crime is treason, and he is rightly condemned: in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: war, everyone would admit the justice of his sentence. (86) If a man does
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not keep to his post, but approaches the enemy without the knowledge of his
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: commander, whatever may be his motive, so long as he acts on his own motion,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: even if he advances with the design of defeating the enemy, he is rightly
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: put to death, because he has violated his oath, and infringed the rights of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his commander. (87) That all citizens are equally bound by these rights in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: time of peace, is not so generally recognized, but the reasons for obedience
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are in both cases identical. (88) The state must be preserved and directed
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by the sole authority of the sovereign, and such authority and right have
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: been accorded by universal consent to him alone: if, therefore, anyone else
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attempts, without his consent, to execute any public enterprise, even though
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the state might (as we said) reap benefit therefrom, such person has none
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the less infringed the sovereigns right, and would be rightly punished for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: treason.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (16:89) In order that every scruple may be removed, we may now answer the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: inquiry, whether our former assertion that everyone who has not the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: practice of reason, may, in the state of nature, live by sovereign natural
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: right, according to the laws of his desires, is not in direct opposition to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the law and right of God as revealed. (90) For as all men absolutely
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (whether they be less endowed with reason or more) are equally bound by the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Divine command to love their neighbour as themselves, it may be said that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they cannot, without wrong, do injury to anyone, or live according to their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: desires.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (16:91) This objection, so far as the state of nature is concerned, can be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: easily answered, for the state of nature is, both in nature and in time,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prior to religion. (92) No one knows by nature that he owes any obedience to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God [Endnote 28], nor can he attain thereto by any exercise of his reason,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but solely by revelation confirmed by signs. (93) Therefore, previous to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: revelation, no one is bound by a Divine law and right of which he is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily in ignorance. (94) The state of nature must by no means be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: confounded with a state of religion, but must be conceived as without
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: either religion or law, and consequently without sin or wrong: this is how
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we have described it, and we are confirmed by the authority of Paul. (95) It
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is not only in respect of ignorance that we conceive the state of nature as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prior to, and lacking the Divine revealed law and right; but in respect of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: freedom also, wherewith all men are born endowed.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (16:96) If men were naturally bound by the Divine law and right, or if the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Divine law and right were a natural necessity, there would have been no need
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for God to make a covenant with mankind, and to bind them thereto with an
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: oath and agreement.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (16:97) We must, then, fully grant that the Divine law and right originated
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: at the time when men by express covenant agreed to obey God in all things,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and ceded, as it were, their natural freedom, transferring their rights to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God in the manner described in speaking of the formation of a state.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (98) However, I will treat of these matters more at length presently.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [16:8] (99) It may be insisted that sovereigns are as much bound by the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Divine law as subjects: whereas we have asserted that they retain their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: natural rights, and may do whatever they like.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (16:100) In order to clear up the whole difficulty, which arises rather
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: concerning the natural right than the natural state, I maintain that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: everyone is bound, in the state of nature, to live according to Divine law,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the same way as he is bound to live according to the dictates of sound
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason; namely, inasmuch as it is to his advantage, and necessary for his
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: salvation; but, if he will not so live, he may do otherwise at his own risk.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (101) He is thus bound to live according to his own laws, not according to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: anyone else's, and to recognize no man as a judge, or as a superior in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: religion. (102) Such, in my opinion, is the position of a sovereign, for he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: may take advice from his fellow-men, but he is not bound to recognize any as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a judge, nor anyone besides himself as an arbitrator on any question of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: right, unless it be a prophet sent expressly by God and attesting his
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mission by indisputable signs. (103) Even then he does not recognize a man,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but God Himself as His judge.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [16:9] (104) If a sovereign refuses to obey God as revealed in His law,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he does so at his own risk and loss, but without violating any civil or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: natural right. (105) For the civil right is dependent on his own decree; and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: natural right is dependent on the laws of nature, which latter are not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: adapted to religion, whose sole aim is the good of humanity, but to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: order of nature - that is, to God's eternal decree unknown to us.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (16:106) This truth seems to be adumbrated in a somewhat obscurer form by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: those who maintain that men can sin against God's revelation, but not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: against the eternal decree by which He has ordained all things.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (107) We may be asked, what should we do if the sovereign commands anything
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contrary to religion, and the obedience which we have expressly vowed to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God? should we obey the Divine law or the human law? (108) I shall treat of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this question at length hereafter, and will therefore merely say now, that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God should be obeyed before all else, when we have a certain and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: indisputable revelation of His will: but men are very prone to error on
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: religious subjects, and, according to the diversity of their dispositions,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are wont with considerable stir to put forward their own inventions, as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: experience more than sufficiently attests, so that if no one were bound to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: obey the state in matters which, in his own opinion concern religion,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the rights of the state would be dependent on every man's judgment
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and passions. (109) No one would consider himself bound to obey laws framed
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: against his faith or superstition; and on this pretext he might assume
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: unbounded license. (110) In this way, the rights of the civil authorities
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: would be utterly set at nought, so that we must conclude that the sovereign
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: power, which alone is bound both by Divine and natural right to preserve and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: guard the laws of the state, should have supreme authority for making any
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: laws about religion which it thinks fit; all are bound to obey its behests
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: on the subject in accordance with their promise which God bids them to keep.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (16:111) However, if the sovereign power be heathen, we should either enter
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: into no engagements therewith, and yield up our lives sooner than transfer
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to it any of our rights; or, if the engagement be made, and our rights
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: transferred, we should (inasmuch as we should have ourselves transferred the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: right of defending ourselves and our religion) be bound to obey them, and to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: keep our word: we might even rightly be bound so to do, except in those
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cases where God, by indisputable revelation, has promised His special aid
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: against tyranny, or given us special exemption from obedience. (112) Thus we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: see that, of all the Jews in Babylon, there were only three youths who were
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: certain of the help of God, and, therefore, refused to obey Nebuchadnezzar.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (113) All the rest, with the sole exception of Daniel, who was beloved by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the king, were doubtless compelled by right to obey, perhaps thinking that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they had been delivered up by God into the hands of the king, and that the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: king had obtained and preserved his dominion by God's design. (114) On the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other hand, Eleazar, before his country had utterly fallen, wished to give a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proof of his constancy to his compatriots, in order that they might follow
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in his footsteps, and go to any lengths, rather than allow their right and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: power to be transferred to the Greeks, or brave any torture rather than
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: swear allegiance to the heathen. (115) Instances are occurring every day in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: confirmation of what I here advance. (116) The rulers of Christian
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: kingdoms do not hesitate, with a view to strengthening their dominion, to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: make treaties with Turks and heathen, and to give orders to their subjects
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: who settle among such peoples not to assume more freedom, either in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things secular or religious, than is set down in the treaty, or allowed by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the foreign government. (117) We may see this exemplified in the Dutch
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: treaty with the Japanese, which I have already mentioned.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [17:0] CHAPTER XVII - IT IS SHOWN THAT NO ONE CAN, OR
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: NEED, TRANSFER ALL HIS RIGHTS TO THE SOVEREIGN POWER.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: OF THE HEBREW REPUBLIC, AS IT WAS DURING THE LIFETIME
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: OF MOSES, AND AFTER HIS DEATH, TILL THE FOUNDATION
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: OF THE MONARCHY; AND   OF ITS EXCELLENCE. LASTLY, OF
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: THE CAUSES WHY THE THEOCRATIC REPUBLIC FELL, AND WHY
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: IT COULD HARDLY HAVE CONTINUED WITHOUT DISSENSION.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [17:1] (1) The theory put forward in the last chapter, of the universal
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rights of the sovereign power, and of the natural rights of the individual
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: transferred thereto, though it corresponds in many respects with actual
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: practice, and though practice may be so arranged as to conform to it more
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and more, must nevertheless always remain in many respects purely ideal. (2)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: No one can ever so utterly transfer to another his power and, consequently,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his rights, as to cease to be a man; nor can there ever be a power so
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sovereign that it can carry out every possible wish. (3) It will always be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: vain to order a subject to hate what he believes brings him advantage, or to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: love what brings him loss, or not to be offended at insults, or not to wish
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to be free from fear, or a hundred other things of the sort, which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily follow from the laws of human nature. (4) So much, I think, is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: abundantly shown by experience: for men have never so far ceded their power
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as to cease to be an object of fear to the rulers who received such power
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and right; and dominions have always been in as much danger from their own
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: subjects as from external enemies. (5) If it were really the case, that men
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: could be deprived of their natural rights so utterly as never to have any
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: further influence on affairs [Endnote 29], except with the permission of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: holders of sovereign right, it would then be possible to maintain with
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: impunity the most violent tyranny, which, I suppose, no one would for an
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: instant admit.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:6) We must, therefore, grant that every man retains some part of his
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: right, in dependence on his own decision, and no one else's.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (7) However, in order correctly to understand the extent of the sovereign's
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: right and power, we must take notice that it does not cover only those
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: actions to which it can compel men by fear, but absolutely every action
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which it can induce men to perform: for it is the fact of obedience, not the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: motive for obedience, which makes a man a subject.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:8) Whatever be the cause which leads a man to obey the commands of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sovereign, whether it be fear or hope, or love of his country, or any other
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotion - the fact remains that the man takes counsel with himself, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nevertheless acts as his sovereign orders. (9) We must not, therefore,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: assert that all actions resulting from a man's deliberation with himself are
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: done in obedience to the rights of the individual rather than the sovereign:
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as a matter of fact, all actions spring from a man's deliberation with
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: himself, whether the determining motive be love or fear of punishment;
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, either dominion does not exist, and has no rights over its
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: subjects, or else it extends over every instance in which it can prevail on
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: men to decide to obey it. (10) Consequently, every action which a subject
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: performs in accordance with the commands of the sovereign, whether such
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: action springs from love, or fear, or (as is more frequently the case) from
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hope and fear together, or from reverence, compounded of fear and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: admiration, or, indeed, any motive whatever, is performed in virtue of his
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: submission to the sovereign, and not in virtue of his own authority.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:11) This point is made still more clear by the fact that obedience does
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not consist so much in the outward act as in the mental state of the person
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: obeying; so that he is most under the dominion of another who with his whole
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: heart determines to obey another's commands; and consequently the firmest
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: dominion belongs to the sovereign who has most influence over the minds of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his subjects; if those who are most feared possessed the firmest dominion,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the firmest dominion would belong to the subjects of a tyrant, for they are
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: always greatly feared by their ruler. (12) Furthermore, though it is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: impossible to govern the mind as completely as the tongue, nevertheless
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: minds are, to a certain extent, under the control of the sovereign, for he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: can in many ways bring about that the greatest part of his subjects should
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: follow his wishes in their beliefs, their loves, and their hates. (13)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Though such emotions do not arise at the express command of the sovereign
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they often result (as experience shows) from the authority of his power, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from his direction; in other words, in virtue of his right; we may,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, without doing violence to our understanding, conceive men who
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: follow the instigation of their sovereign in their beliefs, their loves,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their hates, their contempt, and all other emotions whatsoever.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:14) Though the powers of government, as thus conceived, are sufficiently
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ample, they can never become large enough to execute every possible wish of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their possessors. (15) This, I think, I have already shown clearly enough.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (16) The method of forming a dominion which should prove lasting I do not,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as I have said, intend to discuss, but in order to arrive at the object I
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have in view, I will touch on the teaching of Divine revelation to Moses in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this respect, and we will consider the history and the success of the Jews,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: gathering therefrom what should be the chief concessions made by sovereigns
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to their subjects with a view to the security and increase of their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: dominion.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [17:2] (17) That the preservation of a state chiefly depends on the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: subjects' fidelity and constancy in carrying out the orders they receive, is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: most clearly taught both by reason and experience; how subjects ought to be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: guided so as best to preserve their fidelity and virtue is not so obvious.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (18) All, both rulers and ruled, are men, and prone to follow after their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: lusts. (19) The fickle disposition of the multitude almost reduces those who
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have experience of it to despair, for it is governed solely by emotions, not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by reason: it rushes headlong into every enterprise, and is easily corrupted
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: either by avarice or luxury: everyone thinks himself omniscient and wishes
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to fashion all things to his liking, judging a thing to be just or unjust,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: lawful or unlawful, according as he thinks it will bring him profit or loss:
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: vanity leads him to despise his equals, and refuse their guidance: envy of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: superior fame or fortune (for such gifts are never equally distributed)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: leads him to desire and rejoice in his neighbour's downfall. (20) I need
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not go through the whole list, everyone knows already how much crime.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: results from disgust at the present - desire for change, headlong anger,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and contempt for poverty - and how men's minds are engrossed and kept
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in turmoil thereby.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:21) To guard against all these evils, and form a dominion where no room
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is left for deceit; to frame our institutions so that every man, whatever
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his disposition, may prefer public right to private advantage, this is the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: task and this the toil. (22) Necessity is often the mother of invention, but
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: she has never yet succeeded in framing a dominion that was in less danger
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from its own citizens than from open enemies, or whose rulers did not fear
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the latter less than the former. (23) Witness the state of Rome, invincible
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by her enemies, but many times conquered and sorely oppressed by her own
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: citizens, especially in the war between Vespasian and Vitellius. (24) (See
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Tacitus, Hist. bk. iv. for a description of the pitiable state of the city.)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:25) Alexander thought prestige abroad more easy to acquire than prestige
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: at home, and believed that his greatness could be destroyed by his own
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: followers. (26) Fearing such a disaster, he thus addressed his friends:
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: "Keep me safe from internal treachery and domestic plots, and I will front
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: without fear the dangers of battle and of war. (27) Philip was more secure
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the battle array than in the theatre: he often escaped from the hands of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the enemy, he could not escape from his own subjects. (28) If you think over
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the deaths of kings, you will count up more who have died by the assassin
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: than by the open foe." (Q. Curtius, chap. vi.)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:29) For the sake of making themselves secure, kings who seized the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: throne in ancient times used to try to spread the idea that they were
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: descended from the immortal gods, thinking that if their subjects and the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rest of mankind did not look on them as equals, but believed them to be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: gods, they would willingly submit to their rule, and obey their commands.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (30) Thus Augustus persuaded the Romans that he was descended from AEneas,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: who was the son of Venus, and numbered among the gods. (31) "He wished
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: himself to be worshipped in temples, like the gods, with flamens and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: priests." (Tacitus, Ann. i. 10.)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:32) Alexander wished to be saluted as the son of Jupiter, not from
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: motives of pride but of policy, as he showed by his answer to the invective
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of Hermolaus: "It is almost laughable," said he, that Hermolaus asked me to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contradict Jupiter, by whose oracle I am recognized. (33) Am I responsible
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for the answers of the gods? (34) It offered me the name of son;
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: acquiescence was by no means foreign to my present designs. (35) Would that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Indians also would believe me to be a god! (36) Wars are carried through
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by prestige, falsehoods that are believed often gain the force of truth."
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (Curtius, viii,. Para. 8.) (37) In these few words he cleverly contrives to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: palm off a fiction on the ignorant, and at the same time hints at the motive
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for the deception.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:38) Cleon, in his speech persuading the Macedonians to obey their king,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: adopted a similar device: for after going through the praises of Alexander
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with admiration, and recalling his merits, he proceeds, "the Persians are
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not only pious, but prudent in worshipping their kings as gods: for kingship
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is the shield of public safety," and he ends thus, "I, myself, when the king
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: enters a banquet hall, should prostrate my body on the ground; other men
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: should do the like, especially those who are wise" (Curtius, viii.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Para. 66). (39) However, the Macedonians were more prudent - indeed, it is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: only complete barbarians who can be so openly cajoled, and can suffer
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: themselves to be turned from subjects into slaves without interests of their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: own. (40) Others, notwithstanding, have been able more easily to spread the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: belief that kingship is sacred, and plays the part of God on the earth, that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it has been instituted by God, not by the suffrage and consent of men; and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that it is preserved and guarded by Divine special providence and aid.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (41) Similar fictions have been promulgated by monarchs, with the object of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: strengthening their dominion, but these I will pass over, and in order to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: arrive at my main purpose, will merely recall and discuss the teaching on
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the subject of Divine revelation to Moses in ancient times.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [17:3] (42) We have said in Chap. V. that after the Hebrews came up out of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Egypt they were not bound by the law and right of any other nation, but were
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: at liberty to institute any new rites at their pleasure, and to occupy
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whatever territory they chose. (43) After their liberation from the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: intolerable bondage of the Egyptians, they were bound by no covenant to any
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man; and, therefore, every man entered into his natural right, and was free
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to retain it or to give it up, and transfer it to another. (44) Being, then,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the state of nature, they followed the advice of Moses, in whom they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: chiefly trusted, and decided to transfer their right to no human being, but
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: only to God; without further delay they all, with one voice, promised to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: obey all the commands of the Deity, and to acknowledge no right that He did
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not proclaim as such by prophetic revelation. (45) This promise, or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: transference of right to God, was effected in the same manner as we have
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceived it to have been in ordinary societies, when men agree to divest
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: themselves of their natural rights. (46) It is, in fact, in virtue of a set
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: covenant, and an oath (see Exod. xxxiv:10), that the Jews freely, and not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: under compulsion or threats, surrendered their rights and transferred them
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to God. (47) Moreover, in order that this covenant might be ratified
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and settled, and might be free from all suspicion of deceit, God did not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: enter into it till the Jews had had experience of His wonderful power by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which alone they had been, or could be, preserved in a state of prosperity
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (Exod. xix:4, 5). (48) It is because they believed that nothing but
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God's power could preserve them that they surrendered to God the natural
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: power of self-preservation, which they formerly, perhaps, thought they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: possessed, and consequently they surrendered at the same time all their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: natural right.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [17:4] (49) God alone, therefore, held dominion over the Hebrews, whose
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: state was in virtue of the covenant called God's kingdom, and God was said
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to be their king; consequently the enemies of the Jews were said to be the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: enemies of God, and the citizens who tried to seize the dominion were guilty
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of treason against God; and, lastly, the laws of the state were called the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: laws and commandments of God. (50) Thus in the Hebrew state the civil and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: religious authority, each consisting solely of obedience to God, were one
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and the same. (51) The dogmas of religion were not precepts, but laws and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ordinances; piety was regarded as the same as loyalty, impiety as the same
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as disaffection. (52) Everyone who fell away from religion ceased to be a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: citizen, and was, on that ground alone, accounted an enemy: those who
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: died for the sake of religion, were held to have died for their country;
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in fact, between civil and religious law and right there was no distinction
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whatever. {in Biblical Hebrew, there was no word for what we call Religion."
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Modern Hebrew has selected a word whose root is "knowledge."} (53) For this
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason the government could be called a Theocracy, inasmuch as the citizens
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: were not bound by anything save the revelations of God.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:54) However, this state of things existed rather in theory than in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: practice, for it will appear from what we are about to say, that the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Hebrews, as a matter of fact, retained absolutely in their own hands the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: right of sovereignty: this is shown by the method and plan by which the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: government was carried on, as I will now explain.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:55) Inasmuch as the Hebrews did not transfer their rights to any other
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de
