text: person but, as in a democracy, all surrendered their rights equally, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cried out with one voice, "Whatsoever God shall speak (no mediator or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mouthpiece being named) that will we do," it follows that all were equally
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: bound by the covenant, and that all had an equal right to consult the Deity,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to accept and to interpret His laws, so that all had an exactly equal share
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the government. [17:5] (56) Thus at first they all approached God
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: together, so that they might learn His commands, but in this first
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: salutation, they were so thoroughly terrified and so astounded to hear God
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: speaking, that they thought their last hour was at hand: full of fear,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, they went afresh to Moses, and said, "Lo, we have heard God
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: speaking in the fire, and there is no cause why we should wish to die:
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: surely this great fire will consume us: if we hear again the voice of God,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we shall surely die. (57) Thou, therefore, go near, and hear all the words
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of our God, and thou (not God) shalt speak with us: all that God shall tell
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: us, that will we hearken to and perform."
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:58) They thus clearly abrogated their former covenant, and absolutely
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: transferred to Moses their right to consult God and interpret His commands:
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for they do not here promise obedience to all that God shall tell them, but
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to all that God shall tell Moses (see Deut. v:20 after the Decalogue, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: chap. xviii:15, 16). (59) Moses, therefore, remained the sole promulgator
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and interpreter of the Divine laws, and consequently also the sovereign
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: judge, who could not be arraigned himself, and who acted among the Hebrews
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the part, of God; in other words, held the sovereign kingship: he alone
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: had the right to consult God, to give the Divine answers to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: people, and to see that they were carried out. (60) I say he alone, for if
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: anyone during the life of Moses was desirous of preaching anything in the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: name of the Lord, he was, even if a true prophet, considered guilty and a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: usurper of the sovereign right (Numb. xi:28) [Endnote 30]. (61) We may here
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: notice, that though the people had elected Moses, they could not rightfully
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: elect Moses's successor; for having transferred to Moses their right of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consulting God, and absolutely promised to regard him as a Divine oracle,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they had plainly forfeited the whole of their right, and were bound to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: accept as chosen by God anyone proclaimed by Moses as his successor. (62) If
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Moses had so chosen his successor, who like him should wield the sole right
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of government, possessing the sole right of consulting God, and consequently
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of making and abrogating laws, of deciding on peace or war, of sending
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ambassadors, appointing judges - in fact, discharging all the functions of a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sovereign, the state would have become simply a monarchy, only differing
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from other monarchies in the fact, that the latter are, or should be,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: carried on in accordance with God's decree, unknown even to the monarch,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whereas the Hebrew monarch would have been the only person to whom the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: decree was revealed. (63) A difference which increases, rather than
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: diminishes the monarch's authority. (64) As far as the people in both cases
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are concerned, each would be equally subject, and equally ignorant of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Divine decree, for each would be dependent on the monarch's words, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: would learn from him alone, what was lawful or unlawful: nor would the fact
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that the people believed that the monarch was only issuing commands in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: accordance with God's decree revealed to him, make it less in subjection,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but rather more. [17:6] (65) However, Moses elected no such successor, but
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: left the dominion to those who came after him in a condition which could not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be called a popular government, nor an aristocracy, nor a monarchy, but a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Theocracy. (66) For the right of interpreting laws was vested in one man,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: while the right and power of administering the state according to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: laws thus interpreted, was vested in another man (see Numb. xxvii:21)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [Endnote 31].
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:67) In order that the question may be thoroughly understood, I will duly
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: set forth the administration of the whole state.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (68) First, the people were commanded to build a tabernacle, which should
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be, as it were, the dwelling of God - that is, of the sovereign authority of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the state. (69) This tabernacle was to be erected at the cost of the whole
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: people, not of one man, in order that the place where God was consulted
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: might be public property. (70) The Levites were chosen as courtiers and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: administrators of this royal abode; while Aaron, the brother of Moses, was
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: chosen to be their chief and second, as it were, to God their King, being
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: succeeded in the office by his legitimate sons.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:71) He, as the nearest to God, was the sovereign interpreter of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Divine laws; he communicated the answers of the Divine oracle to the people,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and entreated God's favour for them. (72) If, in addition to these
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: privileges, he had possessed the right of ruling, he would have been neither
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: more nor less than an absolute monarch; but, in respect to government, he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: was only a private citizen: the whole tribe of Levi was so completely
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: divested of governing rights that it did not even take its share with the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: others in the partition of territory. (73) Moses provided for its support by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: inspiring the common people with great reverence for it, as the only tribe
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: dedicated to God.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:74) Further, the army, formed from the remaining twelve tribes, was
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: commanded to invade the land of Canaan, to divide it into twelve portions,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and to distribute it among the tribes by lot. (75) For this task twelve
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: captains were chosen, one from every tribe, and were, together with
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Joshua and Eleazar, the high priest, empowered to divide the land into
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: twelve equal parts, and distribute it by lot. (76) Joshua was chosen for the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: chief command of the army, inasmuch as none but he had the right to consult
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God in emergencies, not like Moses, alone in his tent, or in the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: tabernacle, but through the high priest, to whom only the answers of God
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: were revealed. (77) Furthermore, he was empowered to execute, and cause the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: people to obey God's commands, transmitted through the high priests; to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: find, and to make use of, means for carrying them out; to choose as many,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: army captains as he liked; to make whatever choice he thought best; to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: send ambassadors in his own name; and, in short, to have the entire control
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the war. (78) To his office there was no rightful successor - indeed, the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: post was only filled by the direct order of the Deity, on occasions of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: public emergency. (79) In ordinary times, all the management of peace and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: war was vested in the captains of the tribes, as I will shortly point out.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (80) Lastly, all men between the ages of twenty and sixty were ordered to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: bear arms, and form a citizen army, owing allegiance, not to its
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: general-in-chief, nor to the high priest, but to Religion and to God.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (81) The army, or the hosts, were called the army of God, or the hosts of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God. (82) For this reason God was called by the Hebrews the God of Armies;
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and the ark of the covenant was borne in the midst of the army in important
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: battles, when the safety or destruction of the whole people hung upon the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: issue, so that the people might, as it were, see their King among them,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and put forth all their strength.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:83) From these directions, left by Moses to his successors, we plainly
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: see that he chose administrators, rather than despots, to come after him;
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for he invested no one with the power of consulting God, where he liked and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: alone, consequently, no one had the power possessed by himself of ordaining
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and abrogating laws, of deciding on war or peace, of choosing men to fill
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: offices both religious and secular: all these are the prerogatives of a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sovereign. (84) The high priest, indeed, had the right of interpreting laws,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and communicating the answers of God, but he could not do so when he liked,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as Moses could, but only when he was asked by the general-in-chief of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: army, the council, or some similar authority. (85) The general-in-chief and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the council could consult God when they liked, but could only receive His
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: answers through the high priest; so that the utterances of God, as reported
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by the high priest, were not decrees, as they were when reported by Moses,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but only answers; they were accepted by Joshua and the council, and only
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: then had the force of commands and decrees {Like the separation of powers in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the United States of America.}
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:86) The high priest, both in the case of Aaron and of his son Eleazar,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: was chosen by Moses; nor had anyone, after Moses' death, a right to elect to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the office, which became hereditary. (87) The general-in-chief of the army
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: was also chosen by Moses, and assumed his functions in virtue of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: commands, not of the high priest, but of Moses: indeed, after the death of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Joshua, the high priest did not appoint anyone in his place, and the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: captains did not consult God afresh about a general-in-chief, but each
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: retained Joshua's power in respect to the contingent of his own tribe,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and all retained it collectively, in respect to the whole army. (88) There
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: seems to have been no need of a general-in-chief, except when they were
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: obliged to unite their forces against a common enemy. (89) This occurred
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: most frequently during the time of Joshua, when they had no fixed dwelling.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: place, and possessed all things in common. [17:7] (90) After all the tribes
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: had gained their territories by right of conquest, and had divided their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: allotted gains, they, became separated, having no longer their possessions
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in common, so that the need for a single commander ceased, for the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: different tribes should be considered rather in the light of confederated
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: states than of bodies of fellow-citizens. (91) In respect to their God and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their religion, they, were fellow-citizens; but, in respect to the rights
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which one possessed with regard to another, they were only confederated:
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they, were, in fact, in much the same position (if one excepts the Temple
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: common to all) as the United States of the Netherlands {or United States of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: America}. (92) The division of property, held in common is only another
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: phrase for the possession of his share by each of the owners singly, and the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: surrender by the others of their rights over such share. (93) This is why
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Moses elected captains of the tribes - namely, that when the dominion was
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: divided, each might take care of his own part; consulting God through the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: high priest on the affairs of his tribe, ruling over his army, building and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fortifying cities, appointing judges, attacking the enemies of his own
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: dominion, and having complete control over all civil and military affairs.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (94) He was not bound to acknowledge any superior judge save God
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [Endnote 32], or a prophet whom God should expressly send. (95) If he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: departed from the worship of God, the rest of the tribes did not arraign him
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as a subject, but attacked him as an enemy. (95) Of this we have examples in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Scripture. (96) When Joshua was dead, the children of Israel (not a fresh
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: general-in-chief) consulted God; it being decided that the tribe of Judah
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: should be the first to attack its enemies, the tribe in question contracted
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a single alliance with the tribe of Simeon, for uniting their forces, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attacking their common enemy, the rest of the tribes not being included in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the alliance (Judges i:1, 2, 3). (97) Each tribe separately made war against
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: its own enemies, and, according to its pleasure, received them as subjects
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or allies, though it had been commanded not to spare them on any conditions,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but to destroy them utterly. (98) Such disobedience met with reproof from
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the rest of the tribes, but did not cause the offending tribe to be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: arraigned: it was not considered a sufficient reason for proclaiming a civil
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: war, or interfering in one another's affairs. (99) But when the tribe of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Benjamin offended against the others, and so loosened the bonds of peace
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that none of the confederated tribes could find refuge within its borders,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they attacked it as an enemy, and gaining the victory over it after three
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: battles, put to death both guilty and innocent, according to the laws of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: war: an act which they subsequently bewailed with tardy repentance.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:100) These examples plainly confirm what we have said concerning the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rights of each tribe. (101) Perhaps we shall be asked who elected the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: successors to the captains of each tribe; on this point I can gather no
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: positive information in Scripture, but I conjecture that as the tribes were
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: divided into families, each headed by its senior member, the senior of all
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: these heads of families succeeded by right to the office of captain, for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Moses chose from among these seniors his seventy coadjutors, who formed with
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: himself the supreme council. (102) Those who administered the government
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: after the death of Joshua were called elders, and elder is a very common
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Hebrew expression in the sense of judge, as I suppose everyone knows;
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: however, it is not very important for us to make up our minds on this point.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (103) It is enough to have shown that after the death of Moses no one man
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wielded all the power of a sovereign; as affairs were not all managed by one
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man, nor by a single council, nor by the popular vote, but partly by one
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: tribe, partly by the rest in equal shares, it is most evident that the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: government, after the death of Moses, was neither monarchic, nor
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: aristocratic, nor popular, but, as we have said, Theocratic.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (104) The reasons for applying this name are:
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:105) I. Because the royal seat of government was the Temple, and in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: respect to it alone, as we have shown, all the tribes were fellow-citizens.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (106) II. Because all the people owed allegiance to God, their supreme
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Judge, to whom only they had promised implicit obedience in all things.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:107) III. Because the general-in-chief or dictator, when there was need
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of such, was elected by none save God alone. (108) This was expressly
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: commanded by Moses in the name of God (Deut. xix:15), and witnessed by the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: actual choice of Gideon, of Samson, and of Samuel; wherefrom we may conclude
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that the other faithful leaders were chosen in the same manner, though it is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not expressly told us.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:109) These preliminaries being stated, it is now time to inquire the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: effects of forming a dominion on this plan, and to see whether it so
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: effectually kept within bounds both rulers and ruled, that the former were
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: never tyrannical and the latter never rebellious.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:110) Those who administer or possess governing power, always try to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: surround their high-handed actions with a cloak of legality, and to persuade
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the people that they act from good motives; this they are easily able to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: effect when they are the sole interpreters of the law; for it is evident
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that they are thus able to assume a far greater freedom to carry out their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wishes and desires than if the interpretation if the law is vested in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: someone else, or if the laws were so self-evident that no one could be in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: doubt as to their meaning. [17:8] (111) We thus see that the power of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: evil-doing was greatly curtailed for the Hebrew captains by the fact that the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whole interpretation of the law was vested in the Levites (Deut. xxi:5),
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: who, on their part, had no share in the government, and depended for all
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their support and consideration on a correct interpretation of the laws
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: entrusted to them. (112) Moreover, the whole people was commanded to come
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: together at a certain place every seven years and be instructed in the law
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by the high-priest; further, each individual was bidden to read the book of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the law through and through continually with scrupulous care. (Deut. xxxi:9,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: 10, and vi:7.) (113) The captains were thus for their own sakes bound to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: take great care to administer everything according to the laws laid down,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and well known to all, if they, wished to be held in high honour by, the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: people, who would regard them as the administrators of God's dominion, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as God's vicegerents; otherwise they could not have escaped all the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: virulence of theological hatred. (114) There was another very important
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: check on the unbridled license of the captains, in the fact, that the army
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: was formed from the whole body, of the citizens, between the ages of twenty
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and sixty, without exception, and that the captains were not able to hire
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: any foreign soldiery. (115) This I say was very, important, for it is well
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: known that princes can oppress their peoples with the single aid of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the soldiery in their pay; while there is nothing more formidable to them
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: than the freedom of citizen soldiers, who have established the freedom and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: glory of their country, by their valour, their toil, and their blood. (116)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Thus Alexander, when he was about to make wax on Darius, a second time,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: after hearing the advice of Parmenio, did not chide him who gave the advice,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but Polysperchon, who was standing by. (117) For, as Curtius says
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (iv. Para. 13), he did not venture to reproach Parmenio again after having
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: shortly, before reproved him too sharply. (118) This freedom of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Macedonians, which he so dreaded, he was not able to subdue till after the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: number of captives enlisted in the army, surpassed that of his own people:
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: then, but not till then, he gave rein to his anger so long checked by, the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: independence of his chief fellow-countrymen.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:119) If this independence of citizen soldiers can restrain the princes
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of ordinary states who are wont to usurp the whole glory of victories, it
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: must have been still more effectual against the Hebrew captains, whose
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: soldiers were fighting, not for the glory of a prince, but for the glory of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God, and who did not go forth to battle till the Divine assent had been
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: given.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:120) We must also remember that the Hebrew captains were associated only
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by the bonds of religion: therefore, if any one of them had transgressed,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and begun to violate the Divine right, he might have been treated by the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rest as an enemy and lawfully subdued.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:121) An additional check may be found in the fear of a new prophet
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: arising, for if a man of unblemished life could show by certain signs that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he was really a prophet, he ipso facto obtained the sovereign right to rule,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which was given to him, as to Moses formerly, in the name of God, as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: revealed to himself alone; not merely through the high priest, as in the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: case of the captains. (122) There is no doubt that such an one would easily
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be able to enlist an oppressed people in his cause, and by trifling signs
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: persuade them of anything he wished: on the other hand, if affairs were well
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ordered, the captain would be able to make provision in time; that the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophet should be submitted to his approval, and be examined whether he were
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: really of unblemished life, and possessed indisputable signs of his mission:
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: also, whether the teaching he proposed to set forth in the name of the Lord
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: agreed with received doctrines, and the general laws of the country; if his
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: credentials were insufficient, or his doctrines new, he could lawfully be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: put to death, or else received on the captain's sole responsibility and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: authority.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:123) Again, the captains were not superior to the others in nobility or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: birth, but only administered the government in virtue of their age and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: personal qualities. (124) Lastly, neither captains nor army had any reason
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for preferring war to peace. (125) The army, as we have stated, consisted
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: entirely of citizens, so that affairs were managed by the same persons both
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in peace and war. (126) The man who was a soldier in the camp was a citizen
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the market-place, he who was a leader in the camp was a judge in the law
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: courts, he who was a general in the camp was a ruler in the state. (127)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Thus no one could desire war for its own sake, but only for the sake of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: preserving peace and liberty; possibly the captains avoided change as far as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: possible, so as not to be obliged to consult the high priest and submit to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the indignity of standing in his presence.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:128) So much for the precautions for keeping the captains within bounds.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [17:9] (129) We must now look for the restraints upon the people: these,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: however, are very clearly indicated in the very groundwork of the social
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fabric.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:130) Anyone who gives the subject the slightest attention, will see that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the state was so ordered as to inspire the most ardent patriotism in the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hearts of the citizens, so that the latter would be very hard to persuade to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: betray their country, and be ready to endure anything rather than
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: submit to a foreign yoke. (131) After they had transferred their right
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to God, they thought that their kingdom belonged to God, and that they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: themselves were God's children. (132) Other nations they looked upon as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God's enemies, and regarded with intense hatred (which they took
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to be piety, see Psalm cxxxix:21, 22): nothing would have been more
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: abhorrent to them than swearing allegiance to a foreigner, and promising him
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: obedience: nor could they conceive any greater or more execrable crime than
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the betrayal of their country, the kingdom of the God whom they adored.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:133) It was considered wicked for anyone to settle outside of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: country, inasmuch as the worship of God by which they were bound could not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be carried on elsewhere: their own land alone was considered holy, the rest
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the earth unclean and profane.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:134) David, who was forced to live in exile, complained before Saul as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: follows: "But if they be the children of men who have stirred thee up
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: against me, cursed be they before the Lord; for they have driven me out this
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: day from abiding in the inheritance of the Lord, saying, Go, serve other
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: gods." (I Sam. xxvi:19.) (135) For the same reason no citizen, as we should
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: especially remark, was ever sent into exile: he who sinned was liable to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: punishment, but not to disgrace.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:136) Thus the love of the Hebrews for their country was not only
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: patriotism, but also piety, and was cherished and nurtured by daily rites
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: till, like their hatred of other nations, it must have passed into their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature. (137) Their daily worship was not only different from that of other
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nations (as it might well be, considering that they were a peculiar people
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and entirely apart from the rest), it was absolutely contrary. (138) Such
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: daily reprobation naturally gave rise to a lasting hatred, deeply implanted
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the heart: for of all hatreds none is more deep and tenacious than
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that which springs from extreme devoutness or piety, and is itself cherished
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as pious. (139) Nor was a general cause lacking for inflaming such hatred
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: more and more, inasmuch as it was reciprocated; the surrounding nations
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: regarding the Jews with a hatred just as intense.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:140) How great was the effect of all these causes, namely, freedom from
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man's dominion; devotion to their country; absolute rights over all
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other men; a hatred not only permitted but pious; a contempt for their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fellow-men; the singularity of their customs and religious rites; the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: effect, I repeat, of all these causes in strengthening the hearts of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Jews to bear all things for their country, with extraordinary constancy and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: valour, will at once be discerned by reason and attested by experience.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (141) Never, so long as the city was standing, could they endure to remain
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: under foreign dominion; and therefore they called Jerusalem "a rebellious
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: city" (Ezra iv:12). (142) Their state after its reestablishment (which was a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mere shadow of the first, for the high priests had usurped the rights of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: tribal captains) was, with great difficulty, destroyed by the Romans, as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Tacitus bears witness (Hist. ii:4):- "Vespasian had closed the war against
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Jews, abandoning the siege of Jerusalem as an enterprise difficult
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and arduous rather from the character of the people and the obstinacy of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their superstition, than from the strength left to the besieged for meeting
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their necessities." (143) But besides these characteristics, which are
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: merely ascribed by an individual opinion, there was one feature
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: peculiar to this state and of great importance in retaining the affections
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the citizens, and checking all thoughts of desertion, or abandonment of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the country: namely, self-interest, the strength and life of all human
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: action. (144) This was peculiarly engaged in the Hebrew state, for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nowhere else did citizens possess their goods so securely, as did the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: subjects of this community, for the latter possessed as large a share in the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: land and the fields as did their chiefs, and were owners of their plots of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ground in perpetuity; for if any man was compelled by poverty to sell his
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: farm or his pasture, he received it back again intact at the year of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: jubilee: there were other similar enactments against the possibility of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: alienating real property.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:145) Again, poverty w as nowhere more endurable than in a country where
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: duty towards one's neighbour, that is, one's fellow-citizen, was practised
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with the utmost piety, as a means of gaining the favour of God the King.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (146) Thus the Hebrew citizens would nowhere be so well off as in their own
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: country; outside its limits they met with nothing but loss and disgrace.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:147) The following considerations were of weight, not only in keeping
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: them at home, but also in preventing civil war and removing causes of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: strife; no one was bound to serve his equal, but only to serve God, while
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: charity and love towards fellow-citizens was accounted the highest piety;
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this last feeling was not a little fostered by the general hatred with which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they regarded foreign nations and were regarded by them. (148) Furthermore,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the strict discipline of obedience in which they were brought up, was a very
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: important factor; for they were bound to carry on all their actions
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: according to the set rules of the law: a man might not plough when he liked,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but only at certain times, in certain years, and with one sort of beast at a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: time; so, too, he might only sow and reap in a certain method and season -
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in fact, his whole life was one long school of obedience (see Chap. V. on
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the use of ceremonies); such a habit was thus engendered, that conformity
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: seemed freedom instead of servitude, and men desired what was commanded
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rather than what was forbidden. (149) This result was not a little aided by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the fact that the people were bound, at certain seasons of the year, to give
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: themselves up to rest and rejoicing, not for their own pleasure, but in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: order that they might worship God cheerfully.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:150) Three times in the year they feasted before the Lord; on the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: seventh day of every week they were bidden to abstain from all work and to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rest; besides these, there were other occasions when innocent rejoicing and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: feasting were not only allowed but enjoined. (151) I do not think any better
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: means of influencing men's minds could be devised; for there is no more
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: powerful attraction than joy springing from devotion, a mixture of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: admiration and love. (152) It was not easy to be wearied by constant
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: repetition, for the rites on the various festivals were varied and recurred
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: seldom. (153) We may add the deep reverence for the Temple which all most
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: religiously fostered, on account of the peculiar rites and duties that they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: were obliged to perform before approaching thither. (154) Even now, Jews
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cannot read without horror of the crime of Manasseh, who dared to place an
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: idol in the Temple. (155) The laws, scrupulously preserved in the inmost
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sanctuary, were objects of equal reverence to the people. (156) Popular
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reports and misconceptions were, therefore, very little to be feared
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in this quarter, for no one dared decide on sacred matters, but all
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: felt bound to obey, without consulting their reason, all the commands given
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by the answers of God received in the Temple, and all the laws which God
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: had ordained.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:157) I think I have now explained clearly, though briefly, the main
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: features of the Hebrew commonwealth. (158) I must now inquire into the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: causes which led the people so often to fall away from the law, which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: brought about their frequent subjection, and, finally, the complete
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: destruction of their dominion. (159) Perhaps I shall be told that it sprang
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from their hardness of heart; but this is childish, for why should this
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: people be more hard of heart than others; was it by nature?
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [17:A] (160) But nature forms individuals, not peoples; the latter are
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: only distinguishable by the difference of their language, their customs, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their laws; while from the two last - i.e., customs and laws, - it may arise
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that they have a peculiar disposition, a peculiar manner of life, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: peculiar prejudices. (161) If, then, the Hebrews were harder of heart than
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other nations, the fault lay with their laws or customs.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:162) This is certainly true, in the sense that, if God had wished their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: dominion to be more lasting, He would have given them other rites and laws,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and would have instituted a different form of government. (163) We can,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, only say that their God was angry with them, not only, as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Jeremiah says, from the building of the city, but even from the founding of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their laws.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:164) This is borne witness to by Ezekiel xx:25: "Wherefore I gave them
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: also statutes that were not good, and judgments whereby they should not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: live; and I polluted them in their own gifts, in that they caused to pass
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: through the fire all that openeth the womb; that I might make them desolate,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to the end that they might know that I am the Lord."
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:165) In order that we may understand these words, and the destruction of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Hebrew commonwealth, we must bear in mind that it had at first been
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: intended to entrust the whole duties of the priesthood to the firstborn, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not to the Levites (see Numb. viii:17). (166) It was only when all the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: tribes, except the Levites, worshipped the golden calf, that the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: firstborn were rejected and defiled, and the Levites chosen in their stead
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (Deut. x:8). (167) When I reflect on this change, I feel disposed to break
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: forth with the words of Tacitus. (168) God's object at that time was not the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: safety of the Jews, but vengeance. (169) I am greatly astonished that the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: celestial mind was so inflamed with anger that it ordained laws, which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: always are supposed to promote the honour, well-being, and security of a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: people, with the purpose of vengeance, for the sake of punishment; so that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the laws do not seem so much laws - that is, the safeguard of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the people - as pains and penalties.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:170) The gifts which the people were obliged to bestow on the Levites
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and priests - the redemption of the firstborn, the poll-tax due to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Levites, the privilege possessed by the latter of the sole performance of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sacred rites - all these, I say, were a continual reproach to the people, a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: continual reminder of their defilement and rejection. (171) Moreover, we may
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be sure that the Levites were for ever heaping reproaches upon them: for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: among so many thousands there must have been many importunate dabblers in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: theology. (172) Hence the people got into the way of watching the acts of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Levites, who were but human; of accusing the whole body of the faults of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: one member, and continually murmuring.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:173) Besides this, there was the obligation to keep in idleness men
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hateful to them, and connected by no ties of blood. (174) Especially would
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this seem grievous when provisions were dear. What wonder, then, if in times
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of peace, when striking miracles had ceased, and no men of paramount
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: authority were forthcoming, the irritable and greedy temper of the people
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: began to wax cold, and at length to fall away from a worship, which, though
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Divine, was also humiliating, and even hostile, and to seek after something
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fresh; or can we be surprised that the captains, who always adopt the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: popular course, in order to gain the sovereign power for themselves by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: enlisting the sympathies of the people, and alienating the high priest,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: should have yielded to their demands, and introduced a new worship? (175) If
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the state had been formed according to the original intention, the rights
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and honour of all the tribes would have been equal, and everything would
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have rested on a firm basis. (176) Who is there who would willingly violate
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the religious rights of his kindred? (177) What could a man desire more than
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to support his own brothers and parents, thus fulfilling the duties of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: religion? (178) Who would not rejoice in being taught by them the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: interpretation of the laws, and receiving through them the answers of God?
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:179) The tribes would thus have been united by a far closer bond, if all
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: alike had possessed the right to the priesthood. (180) All danger would have
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: been obviated, if the choice of the Levites had not been dictated by anger
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and revenge. (181) But, as we have said, the Hebrews had offended their God,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Who, as Ezekiel says, polluted them in their own gifts by rejecting all that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: openeth the womb, so that He might destroy them.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:182) This passage is also confirmed by their history. As soon as the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: people in the wilderness began to live in ease and plenty, certain men of no
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mean birth began to rebel against the choice of the Levites, and to make it
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a cause for believing that Moses had not acted by the commands of God, but
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for his own good pleasure, inasmuch as he had chosen his own tribe before
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: all the rest, and had bestowed the high priesthood in perpetuity on his own
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: brother. (183) They, therefore, stirred up a tumult, and came to him, crying
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: out that all men were equally sacred, and that he had exalted himself above
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his fellows wrongfully. (184) Moses was not able to pacify them with
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reasons; but by the intervention of a miracle in proof of the faith, they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: all perished. (185) A fresh sedition then arose among the whole people, who
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: believed that their champions had not been put to death by the judgment of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God, but by the device of Moses. (186) After a great slaughter, or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pestilence, the rising subsided from inanition, but in such a manner that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: all preferred death to life under such conditions.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:187) We should rather say that sedition ceased than that harmony was
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: re-established. (188) This is witnessed by Scripture (Deut. xxxi:21), where
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God, after predicting to Moses that the people after his death will fall
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: away from the Divine worship, speaks thus: "For I know their imagination
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which they go about, even now before I have brought them into the land which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I sware;" and, a little while after (xxxi:27), Moses says: For I know thy
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rebellion and thy stiff neck: behold while I am yet alive with you this
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: day, ye have been rebellious against the Lord; and how much more after my
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: death!"
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:189) Indeed, it happened according to his words, as we all know.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (190) Great changes, extreme license, luxury, and hardness of heart grew up;
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things went from bad to worse, till at last the people, after being
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: frequently conquered, came to an open rupture with the Divine right, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wished for a mortal king, so that the seat of government might be the Court,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: instead of the Temple, and that the tribes might remain fellow-citizens in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: respect to their king, instead of in respect to Divine right and the high
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: priesthood.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:191) A vast material for new seditions was thus produced, eventually
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: resulting in the ruin of the entire state. Kings are above all things
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: jealous of a precarious rule, and can in nowise brook a dominion within
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their own. (192) The first monarchs, being chosen from the ranks of private
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: citizens, were content with the amount of dignity to which they had risen;
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but their sons, who obtained the throne by right of inheritance, began
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: gradually to introduce changes, so as to get all the sovereign rights into
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their own hands. (193) This they were generally unable to accomplish, so
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: long as the right of legislation did not rest with them, but with the high
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: priest, who kept the laws in the sanctuary, and interpreted them to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: people. (194) The kings were thus bound to obey the laws as much as were the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: subjects, and were unable to abrogate them, or to ordain new laws of equal
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: authority; moreover, they were prevented by the Levites from administering
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the affairs of religion, king and subject being alike unclean. (195) Lastly,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the whole safety of their dominion depended on the will of one man, if that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man appeared to be a prophet; and of this they had seen an example, namely,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: how completely Samuel had been able to command Saul, and how easily, because
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of a single disobedience, he had been able to transfer the right of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sovereignty to David. (196) Thus the kings found a dominion within their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: own, and wielded a precarious sovereignty.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:197) In order to surmount these difficulties, they allowed other temples
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to be dedicated to the gods, so that there might be no further need of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consulting the Levites; they also sought out many who prophesied in the name
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of God, so that they might have creatures of their own to oppose to the true
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
