author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophets. (198) However, in spite of all their attempts, they never
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: attained their end. (199) For the prophets, prepared against every
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emergency, waited for a favourable opportunity, such as the beginning of a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: new reign, which is always precarious, while the memory of the previous
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reign remains green. (200) At these times they could easily pronounce by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Divine authority that the king was tyrannical, and could produce a champion
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of distinguished virtue to vindicate the Divine right, and lawfully to claim
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: dominion, or a share in it. (201) Still, not even so could the prophets
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: effect much. (202) They could, indeed, remove a tyrant; but there were
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reasons which prevented them from doing more than setting up, at great cost
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of civil bloodshed, another tyrant in his stead. (203) Of discords and civil
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wars there was no end, for the causes for the violation of Divine right
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: remained always the same, and could only be removed by a complete
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: remodelling of the state.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (17:204) We have now seen how religion was introduced into the Hebrew
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: commonwealth, and how the dominion might have lasted for ever, if the just
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wrath of the Lawgiver had allowed it. (205) As this was impossible, it was
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: bound in time to perish. (206) I am now speaking only of the first
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: commonwealth, for the second was a mere shadow of the first, inasmuch as the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: people were bound by the rights of the Persians to whom they were subject.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (207) After the restoration of freedom, the high priests usurped the rights
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the secular chiefs, and thus obtained absolute dominion. (208) The
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: priests were inflamed with an intense desire to wield the powers of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sovereignty and the high priesthood at the same time. (209) I have,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, no need to speak further of the second commonwealth. (210)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Whether the first, in so far as we deem it to have been durable, is capable
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of imitation, and whether it would be pious to copy it as far as possible,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will appear from what fellows. (211) I wish only to draw attention, as a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: crowning conclusion, to the principle indicated already - namely, that it is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: evident, from what we have stated in this chapter, that the Divine right, or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the right of religion, originates in a compact: without such compact,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: none but natural rights exist. (212) The Hebrews were not bound by their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: religion to evince any pious care for other nations not included in the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: compact, but only for their own fellow-citizens.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [18:0] CHAPTER XVIII - FROM THE COMMONWEALTH OF THE HEBREWS, AND
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: THEIR HISTORY,  CERTAIN POLITICAL DOCTRINES ARE DEDUCED.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [18:1] (1) Although the commonwealth of the Hebrews, as we have conceived
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it, might have lasted for ever, it would be impossible to imitate it at the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: present day, nor would it be advisable so to do. (2) If a people wished to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: transfer their rights to God it would be necessary to make an express
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: covenant with Him, and for this would be needed not only the consent of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: those transferring their rights, but also the consent of God. (3) God,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: however, has revealed through his Apostles that the covenant of God is no
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: longer written in ink, or on tables of stone, but with the Spirit of God in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the fleshy tables of the heart.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (18:4) Furthermore, such a form of government would only be available for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: those who desire to have no foreign relations, but to shut themselves up
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: within their own frontiers, and to live apart from the rest of the world; it
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: would be useless to men who must have dealings with other nations; so that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the cases where it could be adopted are very few indeed.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (18:5) Nevertheless, though it could not be copied in its entirety, it
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: possessed many excellent features which might be brought to our notice, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perhaps imitated with advantage. (6) My intention, however, is not to write
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a treatise on forms of government, so I will pass over most of such points
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in silence, and will only touch on those which bear upon my purpose.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (18:7) God's kingdom is not infringed upon by the choice of an earthly ruler
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endowed with sovereign rights; for after the Hebrews had transferred their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rights to God, they conferred the sovereign right of ruling on Moses,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: investing him with the sole power of instituting and abrogating laws in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the name of God, of choosing priests, of judging, of teaching, of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: punishing - in fact, all the prerogatives of an absolute monarch.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (18:8) Again, though the priests were the interpreters of the laws, they had
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: no power to judge the citizens, or to excommunicate anyone: this could only
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be done by the judges and chiefs chosen from among the people. (9) A
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consideration of the successes and the histories of the Hebrews will bring
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to light other considerations worthy of note. To wit:
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (18:9) I. That there were no religious sects, till after the high priests,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the second commonwealth, possessed the authority to make decrees, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: transact the business of government. (10) In order that such authority might
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: last for ever, the high priests usurped the rights of secular rulers, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: at last wished to be styled kings. (11) The reason for this is ready to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hand; in the first commonwealth no decrees could bear the name of the high
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: priest, for he had no right to ordain laws, but only to give the answers of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God to questions asked by the captains or the councils: he had, therefore,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: no motive for making changes in the law, but took care, on the contrary, to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: administer and guard what had already been received and accepted. (12) His
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: only means of preserving his freedom in safety against the will of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: captains lay in cherishing the law intact. (13) After the high priests had
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: assumed the power of carrying on the government, and added the rights of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: secular rulers to those they already possessed, each one began both in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things religious and in things secular, to seek for the glorification of his
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: own name, settling everything by sacerdotal authority, and issuing every
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: day, concerning ceremonies, faith, and all else, new decrees which he sought
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to make as sacred and authoritative as the laws of Moses. (14) Religion thus
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sank into a degrading superstition, while the true meaning and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: interpretation of the laws became corrupted. (15) Furthermore, while the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: high priests were paving their way to the secular rule just after the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: restoration, they attempted to gain popular favour by assenting to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: every demand; approving whatever the people did, however impious, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: accommodating Scripture to the very depraved current morals. (16) Malachi
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: bears witness to this in no measured terms: he chides the priests of his
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: time as despisers of the name of God, and then goes on with his invective as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: follows (Mal ii:7, 8): "For the priest's lips should keep knowledge,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and they should seek the law at his mouth: for he is the messenger of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Lord of hosts. (17) But ye are departed out of the way; ye have
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: caused many to stumble at the law, ye have corrupted the covenant of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Levi, saith the Lord of hosts." (18) He further accuses them of interpreting
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the laws according to their own pleasure, and paying no respect to God but
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: only to persons. (19) It is certain that the high priests were never so
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cautious in their conduct as to escape the remark of the more shrewd among
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the people, for the latter were at length emboldened to assert that no
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: laws ought to be kept save those that were written, and that the decrees
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which the Pharisees (consisting, as Josephus says in his "Antiquities,"
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: chiefly, of the common people), were deceived into calling the traditions of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the fathers, should not be observed at all. (20) However this may be, we can
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in nowise doubt that flattery of the high priest, the corruption of religion
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and the laws, and the enormous increase of the extent of the last-named,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: gave very great and frequent occasion for disputes and altercations
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: impossible to allay. (21) When men begin to quarrel with all the ardour of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: superstition, and the magistracy to back up one side or the other, they can
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: never come to a compromise, but are bound to split into sects.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (18:22) II. It is worthy of remark that the prophets, who were in a private
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: station of life, rather irritated than reformed mankind by their freedom of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: warning, rebuke, and censure; whereas the kings, by their reproofs and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: punishments, could always produce an effect. (23) The prophets were often
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: intolerable even to pious kings, on account of the authority they assumed
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for judging whether an action was right or wrong, or for reproving the kings
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: themselves if they dared to transact any business, whether public or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: private, without prophetic sanction. (24) King Asa who, according to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the testimony of Scripture, reigned piously, put the prophet Hanani into a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prison-house because he had ventured freely to chide and reprove him for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: entering into a covenant with the king of Armenia.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (18:25) Other examples might be cited, tending to prove that religion
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: gained more harm than good by such freedom, not to speak of the further
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consequence, that if the prophets had retained their rights, great
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: civil wars would have resulted.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (26) III. It is remarkable that during all the period, during which the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: people held the reins of power, there was only one civil war, and that one
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: was completely extinguished, the conquerors taking such pity on the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conquered, that they endeavoured in every way to reinstate them in their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: former dignity and power. (27) But after that the people, little accustomed
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to kings, changed its first form of government into a monarchy, civil war
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: raged almost continuously; and battles were so fierce as to exceed all
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: others recorded; in one engagement (taxing our faith to the utmost)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: five hundred thousand Israelites were slaughtered by the men of Judah, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in another the Israelites slew great numbers of the men of Judah (the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: figures are not given in Scripture), almost razed to the ground the walls of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Jerusalem, and sacked the Temple in their unbridled fury. (28) At length,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: laden with the spoils of their brethren, satiated with blood, they took
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hostages, and leaving the king in his well-nigh devastated kingdom, laid
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: down their arms, relying on the weakness rather than the good faith of their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: foes. (29) A few years after, the men of Judah, with recruited strength,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: again took the field, but were a second time beaten by the Israelites, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: slain to the number of a hundred and twenty thousand, two hundred thousand
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of their wives and children were led into captivity, and a great booty again
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: seized. (30) Worn out with these and similar battles set forth at length in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their histories, the Jews at length fell a prey to their enemies.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (18:31) Furthermore, if we reckon up the times during which peace prevailed
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: under each form of government, we shall find a great discrepancy. (32)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Before the monarchy forty years and more often passed, and once eighty years
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (an almost unparalleled period), without any war, foreign or civil. (33)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: After the kings acquired sovereign power, the fighting was no longer for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: peace and liberty, but for glory; accordingly we find that they all, with
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the exception of Solomon (whose virtue and wisdom would be better displayed
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in peace than in war) waged war, and finally a fatal desire for power gained
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ground, which, in many cases, made the path to the throne a bloody one.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (18:34) Lastly, the laws, during the rule of the people, remained
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: uncorrupted and were studiously observed. (35) Before the monarchy there
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: were very, few prophets to admonish the people, but after the establishment
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of kings there were a great number at the same time. (36) Obadiah saved a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hundred from death and hid them away, lest they should be slain with the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rest. (37) The people, so far as we can see, were never deceived by false
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophets till after the power had been vested in kings, whose creatures many
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the prophets were. (38) Again, the people, whose heart was generally
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proud or humble according to its circumstances, easily corrected it-self
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: under misfortune, turned again to God, restored His laws, and so freed
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: itself from all peril; but the kings, whose hearts were always equally
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: puffed up, and who could not be corrected without humiliation, clung
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pertinaciously to their vices, even till the last overthrow of the city.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [18:2] (39) We may now clearly see from what I have said:-
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (40) I. How hurtful to religion and the state is the concession to ministers
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of religion of any power of issuing decrees or transacting the business of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: government: how, on the contrary, far greater stability is afforded, if the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: said ministers are only allowed to give answers to questions duly put
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to them, and are, as a rule, obliged to preach and practise the received and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: accepted doctrines.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (18:41) II How dangerous it is to refer to Divine right matters merely
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: speculative and subject or liable to dispute. (42) The most tyrannical
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: governments are those which make crimes of opinions, for everyone has an
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: inalienable right over his thoughts - nay, such a state of things leads to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the rule of popular passion.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (18:43) Pontius Pilate made concession to the passion of the Pharisees in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consenting to the crucifixion of Christ, whom he knew to be innocent. (44)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Again, the Pharisees, in order to shake the position of men richer than
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: themselves, began to set on foot questions of religion, and accused the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Sadducees of impiety, and, following their example, the vilest - hypocrites,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: stirred, as they pretended, by the same holy wrath which they called zeal
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for the Lord, persecuted men whose unblemished character and distinguished
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: virtue had excited the popular hatred, publicly denounced their opinions,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and inflamed the fierce passions of the people against them.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (18:45) This wanton licence being cloaked with the specious garb of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: religion could not easily be repressed, especially when the sovereign
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: authorities introduced a sect of which they, were not the head; they were
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: then regarded not as interpreters of Divine right, but as sectarians - that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is, as persons recognizing the right of Divine interpretation assumed by the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: leaders of the sect. (46) The authority of the magistrates thus became of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: little account in such matters in comparison with the authority of sectarian
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: leaders before whose interpretations kings were obliged to bow.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (18:47) To avoid such evils in a state, there is no safer way, than to make
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: piety and religion to consist in acts only - that is, in the practice of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: justice and charity, leaving everyone's judgment in other respects free.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (48) But I will speak of this more at length presently.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [18:3] (49) III. We see how necessary it is, both in the interests of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: state and in the interests of religion, to confer on the sovereign power the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: right of deciding what is lawful or the reverse. (50) If this right of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: judging actions could not be given to the very prophets of God without great
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: injury, to the state and religion, how much less should it be entrusted to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: those who can neither foretell the future nor work miracles! (51) But this
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: again I will treat of more fully hereafter.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (18:52) IV. Lastly, we see how disastrous it is for a people unaccustomed
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to kings, and possessing a complete code of laws, to set up a monarchy. (53)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Neither can the subjects brook such a sway, nor the royal authority submit
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to laws and popular rights set up by anyone inferior to itself. (54) Still
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: less can a king be expected to defend such laws, for they were not framed to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: support his dominion, but the dominion of the people, or some council which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: formerly ruled, so that in guarding the popular rights the king would seem
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to be a slave rather than a master. (55) The representative of a new
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: monarchy will employ all his zeal in attempting to frame new laws, so
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as to wrest the rights of dominion to his own use, and to reduce the people
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: till they find it easier to increase than to curtail the royal prerogative.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (56) I must not, however, omit to state that it is no less dangerous to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: remove a monarch, though he is on all hands admitted to be a tyrant. (57)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: For his people are accustomed to royal authority and will obey no other,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: despising and mocking at any less august control.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (18:58) It is therefore necessary, as the prophets discovered of old, if one
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: king be removed, that he should be replaced by another, who will be a tyrant
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from necessity rather than choice. (59) For how will he be able to endure
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the sight of the hands of the citizens reeking with royal blood, and to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rejoice in their regicide as a glorious exploit? (60) Was not the deed
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perpetrated as an example and warning for himself?
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (18:61) If he really wishes to be king, and not to acknowledge the people as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the judge of kings and the master of himself, or to wield a precarious sway,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he must avenge the death of his predecessor, making an example for his own
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sake, lest the people should venture to repeat a similar crime. (62) He will
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not, however, be able easily to avenge the death of the tyrant by the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: slaughter of citizens unless he defends the cause of tyranny and approves
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the deeds of his predecessor, thus following in his footsteps.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (18:63) Hence it comes to pass that peoples have often changed their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: tyrants, but never removed them or changed the monarchical form of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: government into any other.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [18:4] (64) The English people furnish us with a terrible example of this
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fact. (65) They sought how to depose their monarch under the forms of law,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but when he had been removed, they were utterly unable to change the form of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: government, and after much bloodshed only brought it about, that a new
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: monarch should be hailed under a different name (as though it had been a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mere question of names); this new monarch could only consolidate his power
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by completely destroying the royal stock, putting to death the king's
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: friends, real or supposed, and disturbing with war the peace which might
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: encourage discontent, in order that the populace might be engrossed with
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: novelties and divert its mind from brooding over the slaughter of the king.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (66) At last, however, the people reflected that it had accomplished nothing
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for the good of the country beyond violating the rights of the lawful king
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and changing everything for the worse. (67) It therefore decided to retrace
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: its steps as soon as possible, and never rested till it had seen a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: complete restoration of the original state of affairs.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (18:68) It may perhaps be objected that the Roman people was easily able to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: remove its tyrants, but I gather from its history a strong confirmation of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: my contention. (69) Though the Roman people was much more than
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ordinarily capable of removing their tyrants and changing their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: form of government, inasmuch as it held in its own hands the power of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: electing its king and his successor, said being composed of rebels and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: criminals had not long been used to the royal yoke (out of its six kings it
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: had put to death three), nevertheless it could accomplish nothing
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: beyond electing several tyrants in place of one, who kept it groaning under
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a continual state of war, both foreign and civil, till at last it changed
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: its government again to a form differing from monarchy, as in England, only
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in name.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [18:5] (70) As for the United States of the Netherlands, they have never, as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we know, had a king, but only counts, who never attained the full rights of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: dominion. (71) The States of the Netherlands evidently acted as principals
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the settlement made by them at the time of the Earl of Leicester's
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mission: they always reserved for themselves the authority to keep the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: counts up to their duties, and the power to preserve this authority
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and the liberty of the citizens. (72) They had ample means of vindicating
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their rights if their rulers should prove tyrannical, and could impose
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: such restraints that nothing could be done without their consent and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: approval.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (18:73) Thus the rights of sovereign power have always been vested in the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: States, though the last count endeavoured to usurp them. (74) It is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore little likely that the States should give them up, especially as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they have just restored their original dominion, lately almost lost.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (18:75) These examples, then, confirm us in our belief, that every dominion
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: should retain its original form, and, indeed, cannot change it without
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: danger of the utter ruin of the whole state. (76) Such are the points I have
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: here thought worthy of remark.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [19:0] CHAPTER XIX - IT IS SHOWN THAT THE RIGHT OVER MATTERS
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: SPIRITUAL LIES WHOLLY WITH THE SOVEREIGN, AND THAT
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: THE OUTWARD FORMS OF RELIGION SHOULD BE IN ACCORDANCE
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: WITH PUBLIC PEACE, IF WE WOULD OBEY GOD ARIGHT.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (1) When I said that the possessors of sovereign power have rights over
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: everything, and that all rights are dependent on their decree, I did not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: merely mean temporal rights, but also spiritual rights; of the latter, no
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: less than the former, they ought to be the interpreters and the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: champions. (2) I wish to draw special attention to this point, and to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: discuss it fully in this chapter, because many persons deny that the right
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of deciding religious questions belongs to the sovereign power, and refuse
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to acknowledge it as the interpreter of Divine right. (3) They
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: accordingly assume full licence to accuse and arraign it, nay, even to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: excommunicate it from the Church, as Ambrosius treated the Emperor
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Theodosius in old time. (4) However, I will show later on in this chapter
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that they take this means of dividing the government, and paving the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: way to their own ascendancy. (5) I wish, however, first to point out that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: religion acquires its force as law solely from the decrees of the sovereign.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (6) God has no special kingdom among men except in so far as He reigns
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: through temporal rulers. [19:1] (7) Moreover, the rites of religion and the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: outward observances of piety should be in accordance with the public peace
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and well-being, and should therefore be determined by the sovereign power
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: alone. (8) I speak here only of the outward observances of piety and the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: external rites of religion, not of piety, itself, nor of the inward worship
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of God, nor the means by which the mind is inwardly led to do homage to God
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in singleness of heart.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (19:9) Inward worship of God and piety in itself are within the sphere of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: everyone's private rights, and cannot be alienated (as I showed at the end
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of Chapter VII.). (10) What I here mean by the kingdom of God is, I
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: think, sufficiently clear from what has been said in Chapter XIV.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (11) I there showed that a man best fulfils Gods law who worships Him,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: according to His command, through acts of justice and charity; it follows,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, that wherever justice and charity have the force of law and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ordinance, there is God's kingdom.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (19:12) I recognize no difference between the cases where God teaches and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: commands the practice of justice and charity through our natural faculties,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and those where He makes special revelations; nor is the form of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: revelation of importance so long as such practice is revealed and becomes a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sovereign and supreme law to men. (13) If, therefore, I show that justice
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and charity can only acquire the force of right and law through the rights
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of rulers, I shall be able readily to arrive at the conclusion (seeing that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the rights of rulers are in the possession of the sovereign), that religion
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: can only acquire the force of right by means of those who have the right to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: command, and that God only rules among men through the instrumentality of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: earthly potentates. (14) It follows from what has been said, that the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: practice of justice and charity only acquires the force of law through the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rights of the sovereign authority; for we showed in Chapter XVI. that in the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: state of nature reason has no more rights than desire, but that men living
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: either by the laws of the former or the laws of the latter, possess rights
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: co-extensive with their powers.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (19:15) For this reason we could not conceive sin to exist in the state of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature, nor imagine God as a judge punishing man's transgressions; but we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: supposed all things to happen according to the general laws of universal
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature, there being no difference between pious and impious, between him
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that was pure (as Solomon says) and him that was impure, because there was
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: no possibility either of justice or charity.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [19:2] (16) In order that the true doctrines of reason, that is (as we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: showed in Chapter IV.), the true Divine doctrines might obtain absolutely
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the force of law and right, it was necessary that each individual should
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cede his natural right, and transfer it either to society as a whole, or to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a certain body of men, or to one man. (17) Then, and not till then,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: does it first dawn upon us what is justice and what is injustice,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: what is equity and what is iniquity.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (19:18) Justice, therefore, and absolutely all the precepts of reason,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: including love towards one's neighbour, receive the force of laws and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ordinances solely through the rights of dominion, that is (as we showed in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the same chapter) solely on the decree of those who possess the right to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rule. (19) Inasmuch as the kingdom of God consists entirely in rights
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: applied to justice and charity or to true religion, it follows that (as we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: asserted) the kingdom of God can only exist among men through the means of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the sovereign powers; nor does it make any difference whether religion be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: apprehended by our natural faculties or by revelation: the argument is sound
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in both cases, inasmuch as religion is one and the same, and is equally
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: revealed by God, whatever be the manner in which it becomes known to men.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (19:20) Thus, in order that the religion revealed by the prophets might have
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the force of law among the Jews, it was necessary that every man of them
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: should yield up his natural right, and that all should, with one accord,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: agree that they would only obey such commands as God should
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reveal to them through the prophets. (21) Just as we have shown to take
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: place in a democracy, where men with one consent agree to live according to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the dictates of reason. (22) Although the Hebrews furthermore transferred
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their right to God, they were able to do so rather in theory than in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: practice, for, as a matter of fact (as we pointed out above) they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: absolutely retained the right of dominion till they transferred it to Moses,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: who in his turn became absolute king, so that it was only through him that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God reigned over the Hebrews. (23) For this reason (namely, that religion
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: only acquires the force of law by means of the sovereign power) Moses was
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not able to punish those who, before the covenant, and consequently while
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: still in possession of their rights, violated the Sabbath (Exod. xvi:27),
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but was able to do so after the covenant (Numb. xv:36), because everyone had
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: then yielded up his natural rights, and the ordinance of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Sabbath had received the force of law.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (19:24) Lastly, for the same reason, after the destruction of the Hebrew
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: dominion, revealed religion ceased to have the force of law; for we cannot
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: doubt that as soon as the Jews transferred their right to the king of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Babylon, the kingdom of God and the Divine right forthwith ceased. (25)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: For the covenant wherewith they promised to obey all the utterances of God
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: was abrogated; God's kingdom, which was based thereupon, also ceased. (26)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: The Hebrews could no longer abide thereby, inasmuch as their rights no
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: longer belonged to them but to the king of Babylon, whom (as we showed in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Chapter XVI.) they were bound to obey in all things. (27) Jeremiah (chap.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xxix:7) expressly admonishes them of this fact: "And seek the peace of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: city, whither I have caused you to be carried away captives, and pray unto
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the Lord for it; for in the peace thereof shall ye have peace." (28) Now,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they could not seek the peace of the City as having a share in its
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: government, but only as slaves, being, as they were, captives; by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: obedience in all things, with a view to avoiding seditions, and by observing
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: all the laws of the country, however different from their own. (29) It is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thus abundantly evident that religion among the Hebrews only acquired the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: form of law through the right of the sovereign rule; when that rule was
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: destroyed, it could no longer be received as the law of a particular
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: kingdom, but only as the universal precept of reason. (30) I say of reason,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for the universal religion had not yet become known by revelation. (31) We
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: may therefore draw the general conclusion that religion, whether revealed
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: through our natural faculties or through prophets, receives the force of a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: command solely through the decrees of the holders of sovereign power; and,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: further, that God has no special kingdom among men, except in so far as He
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reigns through earthly potentates.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (19:32) We may now see in a clearer light what was stated in Chapter IV.,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: namely, that all the decrees of God involve eternal truth and necessity, so
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that we cannot conceive God as a prince or legislator giving laws to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mankind. (33) For this reason the Divine precepts, whether revealed through
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: our natural faculties, or through prophets, do not receive immediately from
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God the force of a command, but only from those, or through the mediation of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: those, who possess the right of ruling and legislating. (34) It is only
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: through these latter means that God rules among men, and directs human
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affairs with justice and equity.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (19:35) This conclusion is supported by experience, for we find traces of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Divine justice only in places where just men bear sway; elsewhere the same
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: lot (to repeat, again Solomon's words) befalls the just and the unjust, the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pure and the impure: a state of things which causes Divine Providence to be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: doubted by many who think that God immediately reigns among men, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: directs all nature for their benefit.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [19:3] (36) As, then, both reason and experience tell us that the Divine
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: right is entirely dependent on the decrees of secular rulers, it follows
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that secular rulers are its proper interpreters. (37) How this is so we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: shall now see, for it is time to show that the outward observances of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: religion, and all the external practices of piety should be brought into
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: accordance with the public peace and well-being if we would obey God
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rightly. (38) When this has been shown we shall easily understand how the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sovereign rulers are the proper interpreters of religion and piety.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (19:39) It is certain that duties towards one's country are the highest that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man can fulfil; for, if government be taken away, no good thing can last,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: all falls into dispute, anger and anarchy reign unchecked amid universal
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fear. (40) Consequently there can be no duty towards our neighbour which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: would not become an offence if it involved injury to the whole state, nor
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: can there be any offence against our duty towards our neighbour, or anything
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but loyalty in what we do for the sake of preserving the state. (41) For
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: instance: it is in the abstract my duty when my neighbour quarrels with me
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and wishes to take my cloak, to give him my coat also; but if it be thought
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that such conduct is hurtful to the maintenance of the state, I ought to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: bring him to trial, even at the risk of his being condemned to death.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (19:42) For this reason Manlius Torquatus is held up to honour, inasmuch as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the public welfare outweighed with him his duty towards his children. (43)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: This being so, it follows that the public welfare is the sovereign law to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which all others, Divine and human, should be made to conform. (44) Now, it
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is the function of the sovereign only to decide what is necessary for the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: public welfare and the safety of the state, and to give orders accordingly;
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore it is also the function of the sovereign only to decide the limits
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of our duty towards our neighbour - in other words, to determine how we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: should obey God. (45) We can now clearly understand how the sovereign
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is the interpreter of religion, and further, that no one can obey God
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rightly, if the practices of his piety do not conform to the public welfare;
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or, consequently, if he does not implicitly obey all the commands of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sovereign. (46) For as by God's command we are bound to do our duty to all
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: men without exception, and to do no man an injury, we are also bound not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to help one man at another's loss, still less at a loss to the whole state.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (47) Now, no private citizen can know what is good for the state, except he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: learn it through the sovereign power, who alone has the right to transact
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: public business: therefore no one can rightly practise piety or obedience to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God, unless he obey the sovereign power's commands in all things. (48) This
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proposition is confirmed by the facts of experience. (49) For if the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sovereign adjudge a man to be worthy of death or an enemy, whether he be a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: citizen or a foreigner, a private individual or a separate ruler, no subject
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is allowed to give him assistance. (50) So also though the Jews were
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: bidden to love their fellow-citizens as themselves (Levit. xix:17, 18), they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: were nevertheless bound, if a man offended against the law, to point him out
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to the judge (Levit. v:1, and Deut. xiii:8, 9), and, if he should be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: condemned to death, to slay him (Deut. xvii:7).
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (19:51) Further, in order that the Hebrews might preserve the liberty they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: had gained, and might retain absolute sway over the territory they had
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conquered, it was necessary, as we showed in Chapter XVII., that their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: religion should be adapted to their particular government, and that they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: should separate themselves from the rest of the nations: wherefore it was
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: commanded to them, "Love thy neighbour and hate thine enemy" (Matt. v:43),
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but after they had lost their dominion and had gone into captivity in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Babylon, Jeremiah bid them take thought for the safety of the state into
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which they had been led captive; and Christ when He saw that they would be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: spread over the whole world, told them to do their duty by all men without
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: exception; all of which instances show that religion has always been made to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conform to the public welfare. [19:4] (52) Perhaps someone will ask: By what
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: right, then, did the disciples of Christ, being private citizens, preach
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a new religion? (53) I answer that they did so by the right of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: power which they had received from Christ against unclean spirits (see Matt.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: x:1). (54) I have already stated in Chapter XVI. that all are bound to obey
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a tyrant, unless they have received from God through undoubted revelation a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: promise of aid against him; so let no one take example from the Apostles
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: unless he too has the power of working miracles. (55) The point is brought
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: out more clearly by Christ's command to His disciples, "Fear not those who
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: kill the body" (Matt. x:28). (56) If this command were imposed on everyone,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: governments would be founded in vain, and Solomon's words (Prov. xxiv:21),
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: "My son, fear God and the king," would be impious, which they certainly are
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not; we must therefore admit that the authority which Christ gave to His
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: disciples was given to them only, and must not be taken as an example for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: others.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (19:57) I do not pause to consider the arguments of those who wish to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: separate secular rights from spiritual rights, placing the former under the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: control of the sovereign, and the latter under the control of the universal
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Church; such pretensions are too frivolous to merit refutation. (58) I
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cannot however, pass over in silence the fact that such persons are woefully
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: deceived when they seek to support their seditious opinions (I ask pardon
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: for the somewhat harsh epithet) by the example of the Jewish high priest,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: who, in ancient times, had the right of administering the sacred offices.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (59) Did not the high priests receive their right by the decree of Moses
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (who, as I have shown, retained the sole right to rule), and could they not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by the same means be deprived of it? (60) Moses himself chose not only
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Aaron, but also his son Eleazar, and his grandson Phineas, and bestowed on
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: them the right of administering the office of high priest. (61) This right
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: was retained by the high priests afterwards, but none the less were they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: delegates of Moses - that is, of the sovereign power. (62) Moses, as we have
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: shown, left no successor to his dominion, but so distributed his
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prerogatives, that those who came after him seemed, as it were, regents who
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: administer the government when a king is absent but not dead.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (19:62) In the second commonwealth the high priests held their right
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: absolutely, after they had obtained the rights of principality in addition.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (63) Wherefore the rights of the high priesthood always depended on the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: edict of the sovereign, and the high priests did not possess them till
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they became sovereigns also. (64) Rights in matters spiritual always
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: remained under the control of the kings absolutely (as I will show at the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: end of this chapter), except in the single particular that they were not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: allowed to administer in person the sacred duties in the Temple, inasmuch
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de
