text: as they were not of the family of Aaron, and were therefore considered
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: unclean, a reservation which would have no force in a Christian community.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (19:65) We cannot, therefore, doubt that the daily sacred rites (whose
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: performance does not require a particular genealogy but only a special mode
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of life, and from which the holders of sovereign power are not excluded as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: unclean) are under the sole control of the sovereign power; no one,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: save by the authority or concession of such sovereign, has the right or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: power of administering them, of choosing others to administer them, of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: defining or strengthening the foundations of the Church and her doctrines;
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of judging on questions of morality or acts of piety; of receiving
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: anyone into the Church or excommunicating him therefrom, or, lastly, of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: providing for the poor.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (19:66) These doctrines are proved to be not only true (as we have already
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pointed out), but also of primary necessity for the preservation of religion
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and the state. (67) We all know what weight spiritual right and authority
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: carries in the popular mind: how everyone hangs on the lips, as it were, of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: those who possess it. (68) We may even say that those who wield such
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: authority have the most complete sway over the popular mind.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (19:69) Whosoever, therefore, wishes to take this right away from the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sovereign power, is desirous of dividing the dominion; from such division,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contentions, and strife will necessarily spring up, as they did of old
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: between the Jewish kings and high priests, and will defy all attempts to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: allay them. (70) Nay, further, he who strives to deprive the sovereign power
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of such authority, is aiming (as we have said), at gaining dominion for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: himself. (71) What is left for the sovereign power to decide on, if this
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: right be denied him? (72) Certainly nothing concerning either war or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: peace, if he has to ask another man's opinion as to whether what he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: believes to be beneficial would be pious or impious. (73) Everything would
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: depend on the verdict of him who had the right of deciding and judging what
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: was pious or impious, right or wrong.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (19:74) When such a right was bestowed on the Pope of Rome absolutely, he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: gradually acquired complete control over the kings, till at last he himself
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mounted to the summits of dominion; however much monarchs, and especially
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the German emperors, strove to curtail his authority, were it only by a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hairsbreadth, they effected nothing, but on the contrary by their very
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endeavours largely increased it. (75) That which no monarch could accomplish
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with fire and sword, ecclesiastics could bring about with a stroke of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pen; whereby we may easily see the force and power at the command of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Church, and also how necessary it is for sovereigns to reserve such
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prerogatives for themselves.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (19:76) If we reflect on what was said in the last chapter we shall see that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: such reservation conduced not a little to the increase of religion and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: piety; for we observed that the prophets themselves, though gifted with
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Divine efficacy, being merely private citizens, rather irritated than
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reformed the people by their freedom of warning, reproof, and denunciation,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whereas the kings by warnings and punishments easily bent men to their will.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (77) Furthermore, the kings themselves, not possessing the right in question
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: absolutely, very often fell away from religion and took with them nearly the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whole people. (78) The same thing has often happened from the same cause in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Christian states.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (19:79) Perhaps I shall be asked, "But if the holders of sovereign power
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: choose to be wicked, who will be the rightful champion of piety? (80) Should
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the sovereigns still be its interpreters? "I meet them with the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: counter-question, "But if ecclesiastics (who are also human, and private
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: citizens, and who ought to mind only their own affairs), or if others whom
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it is proposed to entrust with spiritual authority, choose to be wicked,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: should they still be considered as piety's rightful interpreters?" (81) It
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is quite certain that when sovereigns wish to follow their own pleasure,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whether they have control over spiritual matters or not, the whole state,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: spiritual and secular, will go to ruin, and it will go much faster if
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: private citizens seditiously assume the championship of the Divine rights.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (19:82) Thus we see that not only is nothing gained by denying such rights
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to sovereigns, but on the contrary, great evil ensues. (83) For (as happened
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with the Jewish kings who did not possess such rights absolutely) rulers are
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thus driven into wickedness, and the injury and loss to the state become
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: certain and inevitable, instead of uncertain and possible. (84) Whether we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: look to the abstract truth, or the security of states, or the increase of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: piety, we are compelled to maintain that the Divine right, or the right of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: control over spiritual matters, depends absolutely on the decree of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sovereign, who is its legitimate interpreter and champion. (85) Therefore
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the true ministers of God's word are those who teach piety to the people in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: obedience to the authority of the sovereign rulers by whose decree it has
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: been brought into conformity with the public welfare.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [19:5] (86) There remains for me to point out the cause for the frequent
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: disputes on the subject of these spiritual rights in Christian states;
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whereas the Hebrews, so far as I know, never, had any doubts about the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: matter. (87) It seems monstrous that a question so plain and vitally
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: important should thus have remained undecided, and that the secular rulers
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: could never obtain the prerogative without controversy, nay, nor without
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: great danger of sedition and injury to religion. (88) If no cause for this
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: state of things were forthcoming, I could easily persuade myself that all I
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have said in this chapter is mere theorizing, or a kind of speculative
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reasoning which can never be of any practical use. (89) However, when we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reflect on the beginnings of Christianity the cause at once becomes
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: manifest. (90) The Christian religion was not taught at first by kings, but
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by private persons, who, against the wishes of those in power, whose
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: subjects they, were, were for a long time accustomed to hold meetings in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: secret churches, to institute and perform sacred rites, and on their own
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: authority to settle and decide on their affairs without regard to the state,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (91) When, after the lapse of many years, the religion was taken up by the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: authorities, the ecclesiastics were obliged to teach it to the emperors
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: themselves as they had defined it: wherefore they easily gained recognition
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as its teachers and interpreters, and the church pastors were looked upon as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: vicars of God. (92) The ecclesiastics took good care that the Christian
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: kings should not assume their authority, by prohibiting marriage to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: chief ministers of religion and to its highest interpreter. (93) They
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: furthermore elected their purpose by multiplying the dogmas of religion to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: such an extent and so blending them with philosophy that their chief
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: interpreter was bound to be a skilled philosopher and theologian, and to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have leisure for a host of idle speculations: conditions which could only be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fulfilled by a private individual with much time on his hands.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (19:94) Among the Hebrews things were very differently arranged: for their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Church began at the same time as their dominion, and Moses, their absolute
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ruler, taught religion to the people, arranged their sacred rites, and chose
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their spiritual ministers. (95) Thus the royal authority carried very great
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: weight with the people, and the kings kept a firm hold on their spiritual
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prerogatives.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (19:96) Although, after the death of Moses, no one held absolute sway, yet
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the power of deciding both in matters spiritual and matters temporal was in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the hands of the secular chief, as I have already pointed out. (97) Further,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in order that it might be taught religion and piety, the people was bound to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consult the supreme judge no less than the high priest (Deut. xvii:9, 11).
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (98) Lastly, though the kings had not as much power as Moses, nearly the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whole arrangement and choice of the sacred ministry depended on their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: decision. (99) Thus David arranged the whole service of the Temple (see 1
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Chron. xxviii:11, 12, &c.); from all the Levites he chose twenty-four
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thousand for the sacred psalms; six thousand of these formed the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body from which were chosen the judges and proctors, four thousand were
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: porters, and four thousand to play on instruments (see 1 Chron. xxiii:4, 5).
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (100) He further divided them into companies (of whom he chose the chiefs),
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so that each in rotation, at the allotted time, might perform the sacred
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rites. (101) The priests he also divided into as many companies; I will not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: go through the whole catalogue, but refer the reader to 2 Chron. viii:13,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: where it is stated, "Then Solomon offered burnt offerings to the Lord . . .
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: . . after a certain rate every day, offering according to the commandments
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of Moses;" and in verse 14, "And he appointed, according to the order
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of David his father, the courses of the priests to their service . . . .
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: . . for so had David the man of God commanded." (102) Lastly, the historian
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: bears witness in verse 15: "And they departed not from the commandment of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the king unto the priests and Levites concerning any matter, or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: concerning the treasuries."
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [19:6] (103) From these and other histories of the kings it is abundantly
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: evident, that the whole practice of religion and the sacred ministry
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: depended entirely on the commands of the king.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (19:104) When I said above that the kings had not the same right as Moses to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: elect the high priest, to consult God without intermediaries, and to condemn
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the prophets who prophesied during their reign; I said so simply because the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prophets could, in virtue of their mission, choose a new king and give
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: absolution for regicide, not because they could call a king who offended
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: against the law to judgment, or could rightly act against him [Endnote 33].
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (19:105) Wherefore if there had been no prophets who, in virtue of a special
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: revelation, could give absolution for regicide, the kings would have
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: possessed absolute rights over all matters both spiritual and temporal.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (106) Consequently the rulers of modern times, who have no prophets and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: would not rightly be bound in any case to receive them (for they are not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: subject to Jewish law), have absolute possession of the spiritual
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prerogative, although they are not celibates, and they will always retain
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it, if they will refuse to allow religious dogmas to be unduly multiplied or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: confounded with philosophy.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [20:0] CHAPTER XX - THAT IN A FREE STATE EVERY MAN
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: MAY THINK WHAT HE LIKES, AND SAY WHAT HE THINKS.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [20:1] (1) If men's minds were as easily controlled as their tongues, every
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: king would sit safely on his throne, and government by compulsion would
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cease; for every subject would shape his life according to the intentions of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his rulers, and would esteem a thing true or false, good or evil, just or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: unjust, in obedience to their dictates. (2) However, we have shown already
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (Chapter XVII.) that no man's mind can possibly lie wholly at the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: disposition of another, for no one can willingly transfer his natural right
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of free reason and judgment, or be compelled so to do. (3) For this
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason government which attempts to control minds is accounted tyrannical,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and it is considered an abuse of sovereignty and a usurpation of the rights
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of subjects, to seek to prescribe what shall be accepted as true, or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rejected as false, or what opinions should actuate men in their worship of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God. (4) All these questions fall within a man's natural right, which he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cannot abdicate even with his own consent.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (20:5) I admit that the judgment can be biassed in many ways, and to an
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: almost incredible degree, so that while exempt from direct external control
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it may be so dependent on another man's words, that it may fitly be said to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be ruled by him; but although this influence is carried to great lengths, it
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: has never gone so far as to invalidate the statement, that every man's
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: understanding is his own, and that brains are as diverse as palates.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (20:6) Moses, not by fraud, but by Divine virtue, gained such a hold over
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the popular judgment that he was accounted superhuman, and believed to speak
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and act through the inspiration of the Deity; nevertheless, even he could
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not escape murmurs and evil interpretations. (7) How much less then can
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other monarchs avoid them! (8) Yet such unlimited power, if it exists at
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: all, must belong to a monarch, and least of all to a democracy, where the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whole or a great part of the people wield authority collectively. (9) This
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is a fact which I think everyone can explain for himself.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (20:10) However unlimited, therefore, the power of a sovereign may be,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: however implicitly it is trusted as the exponent of law and religion, it can
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: never prevent men from forming judgments according to their intellect, or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: being influenced by any given emotion. (11) It is true that it has the right
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to treat as enemies all men whose opinions do not, on all subjects, entirely
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: coincide with its own; but we are not discussing its strict rights, but its
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proper course of action. (12) I grant that it has the right to rule in the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: most violent manner, and to put citizens to death for very trivial causes,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but no one supposes it can do this with the approval of sound judgment. (13)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Nay, inasmuch as such things cannot be done without extreme peril to itself,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we may even deny that it has the absolute power to do them, or,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consequently, the absolute right; for the rights of the sovereign are
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: limited by his power.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [20:2] (14) Since, therefore, no one can abdicate his freedom of judgment
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and feeling; since every man is by indefeasible natural right the master of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his own thoughts, it follows that men thinking in diverse and contradictory
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fashions, cannot, without disastrous results, be compelled to speak only
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: according to the dictates of the supreme power. (15) Not even the most
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: experienced, to say nothing of the multitude, know how to keep silence. (16)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Men's common failing is to confide their plans to others, though there be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: need for secrecy, so that a government would be most harsh which deprived
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the individual of his freedom of saying and teaching what he thought; and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: would be moderate if such freedom were granted. (17) Still we cannot deny
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that authority may be as much injured by words as by actions; hence,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: although the freedom we are discussing cannot be entirely denied to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: subjects, its unlimited concession would be most baneful; we must,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, now inquire, how far such freedom can and ought to be conceded
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: without danger to the peace of the state, or the power of the rulers; and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this, as I said at the beginning of Chapter XVI., is my principal object.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (18) It follows, plainly, from the explanation given above, of the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: foundations of a state, that the ultimate aim of government is not to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rule, or restrain, by fear, nor to exact obedience, but contrariwise, to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: free every man from fear, that he may live in all possible security; in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other words, to strengthen his natural right to exist and work - without
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: injury to himself or others.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (20:19) No, the object of government is not to change men from rational
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: beings into beasts or puppets, but to enable them to develope their minds
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and bodies in security, and to employ their reason unshackled; neither
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: showing hatred, anger, or deceit, nor watched with the eyes of jealousy and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: injustice. (20) In fact, the true aim of government is liberty.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (20:21) Now we have seen that in forming a state the power of making laws
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: must either be vested in the body of the citizens, or in a portion of them,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or in one man. (22) For, although mens free judgments are very diverse, each
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: one thinking that he alone knows everything, and although complete unanimity
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of feeling and speech is out of the question, it is impossible to preserve
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: peace, unless individuals abdicate their right of acting entirely on their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: own judgment. [20:3] (23) Therefore, the individual justly cedes the right
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of free action, though not of free reason and judgment; no one can act
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: against the authorities without danger to the state, though his feelings and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: judgment may be at variance therewith; he may even speak against them,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: provided that he does so from rational conviction, not from fraud, anger, or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hatred, and provided that he does not attempt to introduce any change on his
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: private authority.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (20:24) For instance, supposing a man shows that a law is repugnant to sound
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason, and should therefore be repealed; if he submits his opinion to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: judgment of the authorities (who, alone, have the right of making and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: repealing laws), and meanwhile acts in nowise contrary to that law, he has
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: deserved well of the state, and has behaved as a good citizen should; but if
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he accuses the authorities of injustice, and stirs up the people against
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: them, or if he seditiously strives to abrogate the law without their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consent, he is a mere agitator and rebel.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (20:25) Thus we see how an individual may declare and teach what he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: believes, without injury to the authority of his rulers, or to the public
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: peace; namely, by leaving in their hands the entire power of legislation as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it affects action, and by doing nothing against their laws, though he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be compelled often to act in contradiction to what he believes, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: openly feels, to be best.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (20:26) Such a course can be taken without detriment to justice and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: dutifulness, nay, it is the one which a just and dutiful man would adopt.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (27) We have shown that justice is dependent on the laws of the authorities,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so that no one who contravenes their accepted decrees can be just, while the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: highest regard for duty, as we have pointed out in the preceding chapter, is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: exercised in maintaining public peace and tranquillity; these could not be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: preserved if every man were to live as he pleased; therefore it is no less
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: than undutiful for a man to act contrary to his country's laws, for if the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: practice became universal the ruin of states would necessarily follow.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (20:28) Hence, so long as a man acts in obedience to the laws of his rulers,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he in nowise contravenes his reason, for in obedience to reason he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: transferred the right of controlling his actions from his own hands to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: theirs. (29) This doctrine we can confirm from actual custom, for in a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conference of great and small powers, schemes are seldom carried
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: unanimously, yet all unite in carrying out what is decided on, whether they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: voted for or against. (30) But I return to my proposition.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (20:31) From the fundamental notions of a state, we have discovered how a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man may exercise free judgment without detriment to the supreme power: from
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the same premises we can no less easily determine what opinions would be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: seditious. (32) Evidently those which by their very nature nullify the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: compact by which the right of free action was ceded. (33) For instance, a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man who holds that the supreme power has no rights over him, or that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: promises ought not to be kept, or that everyone should live as he pleases,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or other doctrines of this nature in direct opposition to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: above-mentioned contract, is seditious, not so much from his actual opinions
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and judgment, as from the deeds which they involve; for he who maintains
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: such theories abrogates the contract which tacitly, or openly, he made with
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his rulers. (34) Other opinions which do not involve acts violating the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contract, such as revenge, anger, and t he like, are not seditious, unless
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it be in some corrupt state, where superstitious and ambitious persons,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: unable to endure men of learning, are so popular with the multitude
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that their word is more valued than the law.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (20:35) However, I do not deny that there are some doctrines which, while
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they are apparently only concerned with abstract truths and falsehoods, are
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: yet propounded and published with unworthy motives. (36) This question we
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have discussed in Chapter XV., and shown that reason should nevertheless
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: remain unshackled. (37) If we hold to the principle that a man's loyalty to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the state should be judged, like his loyalty to God, from his actions only -
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: namely, from his charity towards his neighbours; we cannot doubt that the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: best government will allow freedom of philosophical speculation no less than
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of religious belief. (38) I confess that from such freedom inconveniences
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: may sometimes arise, but what question was ever settled so wisely that no
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: abuses could possibly spring therefrom? (39) He who seeks to regulate
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: everything by law, is more likely to arouse vices than to reform them. (40)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: It is best to grant what cannot be abolished, even though it be in itself
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: harmful. (41) How many evils spring from luxury, envy, avarice, drunkenness,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and the like, yet these are tolerated - vices as they are - because they
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cannot be prevented by legal enactments. (42) How much more then should free
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thought be granted, seeing that it is in itself a virtue and that it cannot
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be crushed! (43) Besides, the evil results can easily be checked, as I will
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: show, by the secular authorities, not to mention that such freedom
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is absolutely necessary for progress in science and the liberal arts: for no
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man follows such pursuits to advantage unless his judgment be entirely free
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and unhampered.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (20:44) But let it be granted that freedom may be crushed, and men be so
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: bound down, that they do not dare to utter a whisper, save at the bidding of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: their rulers; nevertheless this can never be carried to the pitch of making
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: them think according to authority, so that the necessary consequences would
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be that men would daily be thinking one thing and saying another, to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: corruption of good faith, that mainstay of government, and to the fostering
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of hateful flattery and perfidy, whence spring stratagems, and the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: corruption of every good art.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (20:45) It is far from possible to impose uniformity of speech, for the more
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rulers strive to curtail freedom of speech, the more obstinately are
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they resisted; not indeed by the avaricious, the flatterers, and other
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: numskulls, who think supreme salvation consists in filling their stomachs
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and gloating over their money-bags, but by those whom good education, sound
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: morality, and virtue have rendered more free. (46) Men, as generally
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: constituted, are most prone to resent the branding as criminal of opinions
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which they believe to be true, and the proscription as wicked of that which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: inspires them with piety towards God and man; hence they are ready to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: forswear the laws and conspire against the authorities, thinking it not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: shameful but honourable to stir up seditions and perpetuate any sort of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: crime with this end in view. (47) Such being the constitution of human
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature, we see that laws directed against opinions affect the generous
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: minded rather than the wicked, and are adapted less for coercing criminals
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: than for irritating the upright; so that they cannot be maintained without
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: great peril to the state.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (20:48) Moreover, such laws are almost always useless, for those who hold
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that the opinions proscribed are sound, cannot possibly obey the law;
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whereas those who already reject them as false, accept the law as a kind of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: privilege, and make such boast of it, that authority is powerless to repeal
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it, even if such a course be subsequently desired.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (20:49) To these considerations may be added what we said in Chapter XVIII.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in treating of the history of the Hebrews. (50) And, lastly, how many
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: schisms have arisen in the Church from the attempt of the authorities to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: decide by law the intricacies of theological controversy! (51) If men were
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not allured by the hope of getting the law and the authorities on their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: side, of triumphing over their adversaries in the sight of an applauding
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: multitude, and of acquiring honourable distinctions, they would not strive
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so maliciously, nor would such fury sway their minds. (52) This is taught
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not only by reason but by daily examples, for laws of this kind prescribing
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: what every man shall believe and forbidding anyone to speak or write to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contrary, have often been passed, as sops or concessions to the anger of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: those who cannot tolerate men of enlightenment, and who, by such harsh and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: crooked enactments, can easily turn the devotion of the masses into fury and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: direct it against whom they will. (53) How much better would it be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to restrain popular anger and fury, instead of passing useless laws,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which can only be broken by those who love virtue and the liberal arts, thus
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: paring down the state till it is too small to harbour men of talent. (54)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: What greater misfortune for a state can be conceived then that honourable
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: men should be sent like criminals into exile, because they hold diverse
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: opinions which they cannot disguise? (55) What, I say, can be more hurtful
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: than that men who have committed no crime or wickedness should, simply
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: because they are enlightened, be treated as enemies and put to death, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that the scaffold, the terror of evil-doers, should become the arena where
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the highest examples of tolerance and virtue are displayed to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: people with all the marks of ignominy that authority can devise?
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (20:56) He that knows himself to be upright does not fear the death of a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: criminal, and shrinks from no punishment; his mind is not wrung with
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: remorse for any disgraceful deed: he holds that death in a good cause
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is no punishment, but an honour, and that death for freedom is glory.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (20:57) What purpose then is served by the death of such men, what example
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in proclaimed? the cause for which they die is unknown to the idle and the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: foolish, hateful to the turbulent, loved by the upright. (58) The only
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: lesson we can draw from such scenes is to flatter the persecutor, or else to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: imitate the victim.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (20:58) If formal assent is not to be esteemed above conviction, and if
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: governments are to retain a firm hold of authority and not be compelled to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: yield to agitators, it is imperative that freedom of judgment should be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: granted, so that men may live together in harmony, however diverse, or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: even openly contradictory their opinions may be. (59) We cannot doubt that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: such is the best system of government and open to the fewest objections,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: since it is the one most in harmony with human nature. (60) In a democracy
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (the most natural form of government, as we have shown in Chapter XVI.)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: everyone submits to the control of authority over his actions, but not over
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his judgment and reason; that is, seeing that all cannot think alike, the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: voice of the majority has the force of law, subject to repeal if
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: circumstances bring about a change of opinion. (61) In proportion as the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: power of free judgment is withheld we depart from the natural
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: condition of mankind, and consequently the government becomes more
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: tyrannical.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [20:4] (62) In order to prove that from such freedom no inconvenience
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: arises, which cannot easily be checked by the exercise of the sovereign
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: power, and that men's actions can easily be kept in bounds, though their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: opinions be at open variance, it will be well to cite an example. (63) Such
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: an one is not very, far to seek. (64) The city of Amsterdam reaps the fruit
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of this freedom in its own great prosperity and in the admiration of all
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other people. (65) For in this most flourishing state, and most splendid
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: city, men of every nation and religion live together in the greatest
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: harmony, and ask no questions before trusting their goods to a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fellow-citizen, save whether he be rich or poor, and whether he generally
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: acts honestly, or the reverse. (66) His religion and sect is considered of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: no importance: for it has no effect before the judges in gaining or losing
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a cause, and there is no sect so despised that its followers, provided that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they harm no one, pay every man his due, and live uprightly, are deprived
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the protection of the magisterial authority.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (20:67) On the other hand, when the religious controversy between
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Remonstrants and Counter-Remonstrants began to be taken up by politicians
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and the States, it grew into a schism, and abundantly showed that laws
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: dealing with religion and seeking to settle its controversies are much more
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: calculated to irritate than to reform, and that they give rise to extreme
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: licence: further, it was seen that schisms do not originate in a love of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: truth, which is a source of courtesy and gentleness, but rather in an
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: inordinate desire for supremacy, (68) From all these considerations it is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: clearer than the sun at noonday, that the true schismatics are those who
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: condemn other men's writings, and seditiously stir up the quarrelsome masses
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: against their authors, rather than those authors themselves, who generally
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: write only for the learned, and appeal solely to reason. (69) In fact, the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: real disturbers of the peace are those who, in a free state, seek to curtail
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the liberty of judgment which they are unable to tyrannize over.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (20:70) I have thus shown:-
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (71) I. That it is impossible to deprive men of the liberty of saying what
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they think.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (72) II. That such liberty can be conceded to every man without injury
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to the rights and authority of the sovereign power, and that every man
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: may retain it without injury to such rights, provided that he does not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: presume upon it to the extent of introducing any new rights into the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: state, or acting in any way contrary, to the existing laws.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (20:73) III. That every man may enjoy this liberty without detriment to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: public peace, and that no inconveniences arise therefrom which cannot easily
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be checked.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (74) IV. That every man may enjoy it without injury to his allegiance.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (75) V. That laws dealing with speculative problems are entirely useless.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (76) VI. Lastly, that not only may such liberty be granted without prejudice
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to the public peace, to loyalty, and to the rights of rulers, but that it is
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: even necessary, for their preservation. (77) For when people try to take it
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: away, and bring to trial, not only the acts which alone are capable of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: offending, but also the opinions of mankind, they only succeed in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: surrounding their victims with an appearance of martyrdom, and raise
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: feelings of pity and revenge rather than of terror. (78) Uprightness and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: good faith are thus corrupted, flatterers and traitors are encouraged, and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: sectarians triumph, inasmuch as concessions have been made to their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: animosity, and they have gained the state sanction for the doctrines of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which they are the interpreters. (79) Hence they arrogate to themselves the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: state authority and rights, and do not scruple to assert that they have been
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: directly chosen by God, and that their laws are Divine, whereas the laws of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the state are human, and should therefore yield obedience to the laws of God
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: - in other words, to their own laws. (80) Everyone must see that this is not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a state of affairs conducive to public welfare. (81) Wherefore, as we have
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: shown in Chapter XVIII., the safest way for a state is to lay down the rule
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that religion is comprised solely in the exercise of charity and justice,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and that the rights of rulers in sacred, no less than in secular matters,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: should merely have to do with actions, but that every man should think what
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he likes and say what he thinks.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (20:82) I have thus fulfilled the task I set myself in this treatise.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [20:5] (83) It remains only to call attention to the fact that I have
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: written nothing which I do not most willingly submit to the examination and
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: approval of my country's rulers; and that I am willing to retract anything
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which they shall decide to be repugnant to the laws, or prejudicial to the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: public good. (84) I know that I am a man, and as a man liable to error, but
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: against error I have taken scrupulous care, and have striven to keep in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: entire accordance with the laws of my country, with loyalty, and with
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: morality.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: End of Part 4 of 4.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: AUTHOR'S ENDNOTES TO THE THEOLOGICO-POLITICAL TREATISE
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: CHAPTER XVI.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [Endnote 26]. (1) "No one can honestly promise to forego the right which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he has over all things." (2) In the state of social life, where general
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: right determines what is good or evil, stratagem is rightly distinguished as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of two kinds, good and evil. (3) But in the state of Nature, where every man
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is his own judge, possessing the absolute right to lay down laws for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: himself, to interpret them as he pleases, or to abrogate them if he thinks
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it convenient, it is not conceivable that stratagem should be evil.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [Endnote 27]. (1) "Every member of it may, if he will, be free." (2)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Whatever be the social state a man finds; himself in, he may be free. (3)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: For certainly a man is free, in so far as he is led by reason. (4) Now
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason (though Hobbes thinks otherwise) is always on the side of peace,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which cannot be attained unless the general laws of the state be respected.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (5) Therefore the more he is free, the more constantly will he respect the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: laws of his country, and obey the commands of the sovereign power to which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he is subject.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [Endnote 28]. (1) "No one knows by nature that he owes any obedience to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God." (2) When Paul says that men have in themselves no refuge, he speaks as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a man: for in the ninth chapter of the same epistle he expressly teaches
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that God has mercy on whom He will, and that men are without excuse, only
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: because they are in God's power like clay in the hands of a potter, who out
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the same lump makes vessels, some for honour and some for dishonour, not
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: because they have been forewarned. (3) As regards the Divine natural law
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whereof the chief commandment is, as we have said, to love God, I have
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: called it a law in the same sense, as philosophers style laws those general
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rules of nature, according to which everything happens. (4) For the love of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God is not a state of obedience: it is a virtue which necessarily exists in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a man who knows God rightly. (5) Obedience has regard to the will of a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ruler, not to necessity and truth. (6) Now as we are ignorant of the nature
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of God's will, and on the other hand know that everything happens solely by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God's power, we cannot, except through revelation, know whether God wishes
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in any way to be honoured as a sovereign.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (7) Again; we have shown that the Divine rights appear to us in the light of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rights or commands, only so long as we are ignorant of their cause: as soon
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as their cause is known, they cease to be rights, and we embrace them no
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: longer as rights but as eternal truths; in other words, obedience passes
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: into love of God, which emanates from true knowledge as necessarily as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: light emanates from the sun. (8) Reason then leads us to love God, but
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cannot lead us to obey Him; for we cannot embrace the commands of God as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Divine, while we are in ignorance of their cause, neither can we rationally
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceive God as a sovereign laying down laws as a sovereign.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: CHAPTER XVII.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [Endnote 29]. (1) "If men could lose their natural rights so as to be
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: absolutely unable for the future to oppose the will of the sovereign" (2)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Two common soldiers undertook to change the Roman dominion, and did change
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it. (Tacitus, Hist. i:7.)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [Endnote 30]. (1) See Numbers xi. 28. In this passage it is written that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: two men prophesied in the camp, and that Joshua wished to punish them. (2)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: This he would not have done, if it had been lawful for anyone to deliver the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Divine oracles to the people without the consent of Moses. (3) But Moses
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thought good to pardon the two men, and rebuked Joshua for exhorting him to
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: use his royal prerogative, at a time when he was so weary of reigning, that
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he preferred death to holding undivided sway (Numb. xi:14). (4) For he made
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: answer to Joshua, "Enviest thou for my sake? (5) Would God that all the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Lord's people were prophets, and that the Lord would put His spirit upon
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: them." (6) That is to say, would God that the right of taking counsel of God
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: were general, and the power were in the hands of the people. (7) Thus Joshua
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: was not mistaken as to the right, but only as to the time for using it, for
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which he was rebuked by Moses, in the same way as Abishai was rebuked by
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: David for counselling that Shimei, who had undoubtedly been guilty of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: treason, should be put to death. (8) See 2 Sam. xix:22, 23.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [Endnote 31]. (1) See Numbers xxvii:21. (2) The translators of the Bible
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have rendered incorrectly verses 19 and 23 of this chapter. (3) The passage
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: does not mean that Moses gave precepts or advice to Joshua, but that he made
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or established him chief of the Hebrews. (4) The phrase is very frequent in
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Scripture (see Exodus, xviii:23; 1 Sam. xiii:15; Joshua i:9; 1 Sam.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: [Endnote 32] (1) "There was no judge over each of the captains save
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de
