text: God." (2) The Rabbis and some Christians equally foolish pretend that the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Sanhedrin, called "the great" was instituted by Moses. (3) As a matter of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fact, Moses chose seventy colleagues to assist him in governing, because he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: was not able to bear alone the burden of the whole people; but he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: never passed any law for forming a college of seventy members; on the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contrary he ordered every tribe to appoint for itself, in the cities which
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God had given it, judges to settle disputes according to the laws which he
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: himself had laid down. (4) In cases where the opinions of the judges
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: differed as to the interpretation of these laws, Moses bade them take
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: counsel of the High Priest (who was the chief interpreter of the law), or of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the chief judge, to whom they were then subordinate (who had the right of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consulting the High Priest), and to decide the dispute in accordance with
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the answer obtained. (5) If any subordinate judge should assert, that he was
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not bound by the decision of the High Priest, received either directly or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: through the chief of his state, such an one was to be put to death (Deut.
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: xvii:9) by the chief judge, whoever he might be, to whom he was a
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: subordinate. (6) This chief judge would either be Joshua, the supreme
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: captain of the whole people, or one of the tribal chiefs who had been
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: entrusted, after the division of the tribes, with the right of consulting
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the high priest concerning the affairs of his tribe, of deciding on peace or
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: war, of fortifying towns, of appointing inferior judges, &c. (7) Or, again,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it might be the king, in whom all or some of the tribes had vested their
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: rights.(8) I could cite many instances in confirmation of what I here
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: advance. (9) I will confine myself to one, which appears to me the most
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: important of all. (10) When the Shilomitish prophet anointed Jeroboam king,
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he, in so doing, gave him the right of consulting the high priest, of
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: appointing judges, &c. (11) In fact he endowed him with all the rights over
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the ten tribes, which Rehoboam retained over the two tribes. (12)
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Consequently Jeroboam could set up a supreme council in his court with as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: much right as Jehoshaphat could at Jerusalem (2 Chron. xix:8). (13) For it
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is plain that neither Jeroboam, who was king by God's command, nor
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Jeroboam's subjects, were bound by the Law of Moses to accept the judgments
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of Rehoboam, who was not their king. (14) Still less were they under the
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: jurisdiction of the judge, whom Rehoboam had set up in Jerusalem as
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: subordinate to himself. (15) According, therefore, as the Hebrew dominion
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: was divided, so was a supreme council setup in each division. (16) Those who
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: neglect the variations in the constitution of the Hebrew States, and confuse
title: Theologico-Political Treatise — Part 4
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: them all together in one, fall into numerous difficulties.
